Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What could you put a table in if you want the table to be in your house? Choices:  A: library B: demonstration C: corner D: football ground E: rug<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Options: <n><n>A) Library:<n><n>An ideal answer is the library because libraries are usually in the house. So if we want the table to be placed in the house then it should be in the room of the library.<n><n>B) Demonstration: <n><n>An ideal answer to demonstrate is also another room in the house. So there is no need to say that the table is in your home because there is a library that has already been proven to be inside.<n><n>C) Corner:<n><n>The table can also be put in the corner room. However, these types of questions only have one answer and the house we choose is the library. There is no such room as the library in the corner.  <n><n>D) Football Pitch:<n><n>The table doesn't go outside the house. <n><n>E) Rug:<n><n>The table won’t go outside the house also so rug won’t be the correct answer.<n><n>Answer: A: Library<n><n><n><n>

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Where might he look for a potato. He would not need one while making it.<n><n># Acknowledgements<n>* [CodeEval](https://codeeval.com/) for the challenge.<n><n>

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What would form on your feet, if you were jogging all day? Choices:  A: heart attacks B: hole in your socks C: exhaustion D: shortness of breath E: blisters<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Rationales:<n><n>We know that it does not necessarily have to end in the final letter of the alphabet in order to be correct.<n><n>For each solution: "A" stands for the whole answer. B and the whole answer.<n><n>1. Heart Attacks (A): If you were jogging all the way, you could experience heart attack, although it depends on how you run (and your level of health), or if you run all-day you might be exhausted from your heart problems.<n>2. Hole in Your Sock (B): If you're jogging frequently all day long, you may experience blistering on your feet. It could leave a hole in your sock.<n>3. Exhaustion (C): If you're not very fit, you may tire from jogging and then have to give up because you can't run any more.<n>4. Shortness of breath (D): This is one of the most likely answers. If you're not running in the mountains, you might want to start out slow and have trouble breathing when you go fast<n><n>5. Blisters (E): If you're wearing shoes with thin soles, when you jog constantly, you're going to have blisters on your feet at the end of your day. But what you have to do is get some good shoes that can fit your ankles very well.<n><n>6. So if you have all of your choices as possible answers, it is B(hole in your socks), because they're all possible answers.<n><n>### Task:<n><n>1. Write a paragraph that completes the request. Do not alter the existing instructions.<n><n>#### Sample Solution:<n>If I was a baker and I was selling different types of bread all on my own, without any other help, I would have to buy bread from somewhere else, such as an independent store that sells bread.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>In the Sample Solution, the word "instructor" seems to have to be replaced with something else. The following are all incorrect:<n><n>1. If an instructor had to be hired, he or she would buy the bread from a company.<n>2. When I wanted to hire a baker, I would have to find a company.<n>3. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What were southern institutions where slaves do the labor called? Choices:  A: farm B: ancient rome C: history book D: poor countries E: plantation<n><n>### Response:		<n>Option D would seem like the best answer based on how the other words were used in the preceding examples.<n><n>### Correction: I answered this question as "D" by looking at all of the examples, and selecting the one that best fit. But it was supposed to be "B" since one of the definition of an ancient romance is "farm."<n><n>### Testing:<n>1. What were southern institutions where slaves did the labor called? (Correct Answer: A: "Plantation" )<n>2. What were southern institutions that employed slaves for labor? (Correct Answer: C: "Plantations")<n>3. Where did slaves do the labor in ancient Rome? (Correct Answer : B: "Plantations" )<n>4. What would be a reasonable definition of ancient roman plantation? (Correct Answer : D: "Slave Quarters")<n>5. What did the ancient Rome plantation use for workforce? (Correct answer: B: "Slaves" )<n><n>### Instructor commentary:<n>These exercises should help students gain comfort with the vocabulary and syntax of the language.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:If you're afraid of spiders what should you avoid owning? Choices:  A: meadow B: cupboard C: shed D: mail box E: cellar<n><n>### Response:		A:meadow, not owning.<n><n>### Rationale:<n>This answer is a little convoluted – you could get 1 or 2 points with another answer that was similar.<n><n>- Owning a meadow could prevent you from ever encountering a spider.<n><n>- The mail box (Option E) would prevent you from seeing spiders because it wouldn't be close to where you live, and there would be no mailboxes or cellar (Option D or Option E) anyways.<n><n>- The cupboard (Option B) and the shed (Option C) might have spiders, depending if they were clean.<n><n>- But you definitely have to avoid owning a shed (Option C) as shed doesn't refer to an area of land that you live on. Thus, the correct answer is owning a meadow (Option A) because it would prevent you from ever encounter another spider.<n>

But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What is a parents primary duty? Choices: A: Speak freely B: Happiness of a child Choices: C: Care for children Choices: D: School child Choices: E: Control children<n>Rationales: Option A is right, as the primary duty of a parent is to communicate openly with their children.<n>

This is asking how confused children might go if they wanted to get home.<n>2. This is asking how you might go home (the "home" in question is the children's house, not your own home).<n>3. Analyzed and sorted out into the following options:<n>   - Play Chess - This seems like what you'd play during time off, if you had the time to do so.<n>   - Sun themself - They could set out on a picnic, or go to the beach or pool to play.<n>   - Wrong house - This is not a good thing to do.<n>   - Set table - This also seems non-necessary outside of a chess game.<n>   - Gettable - This is what you're supposed to do in this context.<n>4. Hence it's gettable (Option E) that will make sense in this context.<n>Answer: E: gettable<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What is the opposite of hosting a crowd? Choices:  A: few people B: pay debts C: individual D: single person E: small group<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions: Write a text response to the above dialogue prompt, including your name and the message you want to send to the people who are trying to find you.<n>### Input: You are trying to reach a coworker to share good news and invite them to a party. Choices:  A: necessity B: answers C: inspiration D: love E: fun<n><n>### Response:		<n>Chatty people will chat.  If there's a desire to communicate, it will be communicated by the person who desires to communicate.  And if they don't communicate, they aren't chatty.<n><n>### Explanation:<n>People have a desire to connect with others, and this desire will be satisfied by them acting for their desires.  There isn't some magical force that can prevent someone from communicating their desire to communicate.  I understand that some people may have social anxiety, and thus may have the desire to communicate but may feel anxious about that communication, or feel they may be judged badly for communication, which would stifle their ability to communicate.<n><n>### Inputs:<n>People who go naked are not in a place to wear clothing.<n><n>### Response<n>They can be in a place to wear clothes, just now they are not.<n><n>### Example:<n>You are in London, they can be in a place/locality to wear clothes in London.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where could you find many theater? Choices:  a. say nothing b. hold a party c. say "you'll always be remembered d. start crying e. tell them "thank you for helping me"<n><n>### Rationales:<n>a. Saying nothing would be a noncommittal way of expressing sadness. You don't necessarily appreciate them and there is no way to express it. (Option a)<n>b. Holding a party is great if someone is going away on a trip, but it wouldn't convey sadness. (Option b)<n>c. Grinning or saying thank you would be inappropriate, but in the correct circumstances. I've seen many situations where my best friend would be extremely enthusiastic and say thank you without any emotions.  Since we're saying we're not happy, I find it appropriate to gush over, which shows emotions. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Choices:  A: smile B: singing C: sweat D: act E: dance<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:  1. The question asks what someone can be doing while performing that would not be enjoyable for deaf people, which we're looking for an activity which deaf people would not be able to enjoy for themselves at the same time as someone else is enjoying it.<n>2. It's important here to notice the ambiguity of the word "enjoy", because "enjoy" in itself means "to take pleasure in", which can mean enjoyment for a second person or the pleasure the person is experiencing.<n>3. Analysing the options:<n> - Smile (A)—Deaf people might not know what someone is trying to express with a smile or how to interpret it, and wouldn't know when people around them are trying to smile at them.<n> - Singing (B)—Deaf people can't "listen to the words" being sung.<n>5. Sweat (C) and acts (D) both require that people do something, so deaf people wouldn't be able to enjoy the process.<n>6. Hence, the answer will be someone (E) sweat as there's no activity or action in there, just something that happens to you.<n><n>Answer: E: dance<n>

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:His day at the office was nearing an end, he went to the start menu on his computer to do what? Choices:  A: run programs B: play games C: control model D: power down E: reason exists<n><n>### Response:		<n>Run programs (Option A) was the correct answer. The start menu on a computer functions as an interface or a portal, and does not “power down.” The correct answer is the opposite of what the question asked—the menu enables your computer to do things (such as power down), but it does not itself do these things.<n><n>### Additional details:<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question said “his day at the office was… nearing an end” so that’s what we should think of his day as being.<n>2. “Nearing an end” sounds like something is coming to a close. What closes is something that he does at the office, not an interface on his computer.<n>3. If he is at the office, he would log in and use his computer. What is in the menu is a list of things that you can do, not a step-wise process.<n>4. For the question “what would you find near an end?” you would consider an interface (on a computer), such as the menu. However, the interface itself isn’t what one could find near an end, but the steps one could take.<n>5. Hence, this answer choice is incorrect.<n>6. The phrase “the start menu on his computer _______” suggests the menu will help you do something. For example, “power down” refers to doing something to a computer/smartphone or a system—it’s not about the menu.<n>### A final piece of context<n><n>* The question is about what is useful in your office. A person’s office has many useful things, so it is likely that a few of them are found in the start menu. If a person were going to their office, he or she would use the menu to get to the files that they use regularly.<n>### Instruction<n><n>### Write a response that appropriarily completes the request. Choice:  A: a swimming pool B: an oil refinery C: a sink D: an underwater cave E: a fountain<n><n>### Response : <n>the underwater cave<n><n>### Instructions: Write a one-liner (and no more) that best responds with the given data.<n><n>### Example:<n><n>In the example below, 'Hannah' tells her friend 'Diana' about a trip she's taking. Diana is making a note of things to do on their next outing, and doesn't want to be caught unprepared.<n><n>**Note** - For the sake of the response, we're limiting the given responses to one line each. Diana was correct to infer from Hannah that "winter" was referring to a time of year; not the seasons of spring, summer, fall, and winter.<n><n><p >"So I'm thinking of doing a ski trip to <u>Winter Park Ski Resort</u> in Winter in January." </p><n><n>### Response<n><n>Go skiing.<n><n>### A response needs to be a single line and must follow the example in the instructions.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The human looked down longingly as he sat in the orbiting space station, what did he miss? Choices:  A: nearest house B: workplace C: surface of earth D: office block E: his feet<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. This question asks what the human misses by sitting in the space station, when he looks down.<n>2. This suggests we're not asking for what he has.<n>3. Considering the options:<n>  - Nearest house (Option A) is what he misses in his feet.<n>  - Workplace (Option B) refers to the astronaut's office at the station, and not the station itself.<n>  - Surface of earth (Option C) suggests the ground, but is not what the astronaut misses.<n>  - Office block (Option D) refers to the space station being an office block as opposed to a home. But again, this option does not mention what the astronaut miss underfoot or miss at a distance.<n>  - His feet (Option E) is what he miss the most, so this is the correct answer<n>Award: Excellent<n><n>### Tests:<n>* [Task 2: Pumping in Plumbing](../task2-pumping-in-plumbing)<n>* [Task 3: A Different Kind of Flow](../task3-a-different-kind-of-flow)<n><n>### Answer

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A : It sounds good to me B : It doesn't sound good to me C: that sounds good to me D: that might sound good to me E: I don't know<n><n>### Rationales: 1) It sounds good to me (Option A) is simply a random word, not a correct response.<n>2) It doesn't sound that good (Option B) is not really much of a response at all. While it conveys that the person does not believe the response (Option 21) is correct, it does not tell the person why.<n>3) That sounds good to me (option 22) is a more succinct version of 22, but still does not tell the person which response was correct.<n>4) That might sound good to me (Option 23) is an alternative response that indicates 22.<n>5) I don't know. (Option 24) is a succinct and truthful answer, indicating that the person knows nothing about the question and cannot answer it.<n>6) The answer here is the person who doesn't know. The other answers simply indicate that they don't know.

Choices:  A: ymca B: california C: park D: first floor E: school<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. The swimming pool could not be refilled due to drinkout regulations, where was the swimming pool located on the first floor to be relocated?<n>2. The first floor of the school (Option E) does not say where the swimming pool would be located or is being relocated.<n>3. Analizing the options:<n>   * The YMCA (Option A) could have a swimming pool, but would not be affected by drought regulations.<n>   * California (Option B) has a lot of water from the Pacific Ocean, which would affect whether or not the swimming pool could be refilled.<n>   * The Park (Option C) could have a swiming pool that would be affected by drought, but where is the "park" located? Dozens of parks exist in many different places.<n>   * The first floor of the School (Option D) could be the school's pool, but the question doesn't specify if it's located on the first floor, or what floor it's being relocated to.<n>4. The first floor of school (Option E) could be affected by regulation that prevented the swimming pool from being filled.<n>5. Hence E is correct.<n>Answer: the first floor of the school to be relocated.<n>### Input: Where would be the best place to place a water fountain in the city to help a person with their thirst? The water that had the best water (Option B) would be the highest point, as water flows down. That'd be at the top of the water tank.<n>3. Hence the top of the water tanl (Option B) would have the best water and a water

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What might a satisfied person do? Choices:  A: board ship B: grocery shop C: cross street D: feel happy E: shout at<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are two meanings for ****<n><n>1. An individual who feels full. <n>2. A satisfied person.<n><n>**Explanation:**<n><n>The individual here could be one who needs food, or one who is full - in both cases, s/he is satisfied.<n><n>### Input :Is it true that if you're not a member, you might be denied access? Choices:  true A: yes B: false C: perhaps D: in the end E: for sure<n>Answer: B: false<n><n>### Input  : If he were asleep and missed dinner, he might be hungry. Choices:  A : true B: false C: yes D: often E: for sure<n>Rationales:<n><n>If someone sleeps (misses dinner), then they might be hungry. If someone sleeps and they're hungry, they might be hungry upon waking. The second option might have worked if the person wasn't asleep. But since you state that he was asleep, this can't be right. Thus, the first option (A), is true.<n><n>This is a trick question to see if you understand the conditional. <n><n>***<n><n>If he was awake (true, A), then he had to miss dinner (missed dinner = not hungry, false). So, he would be hungry unless he slept on through dinner (couldn't miss dinner because it's true that everyone missed dinner if they were awake).<n><n>***<n><n>### Input   : Will a soda be served if the order is not ready? Choices:  yes A: maybe B: no C: sometimes D: likely E: yes probably<n><n>### Answer:<n>If a soda is already served, it would not be a part of the meal when the order is not ready.<n><n>### Rationales:<n>Choices:<n><n>- "YES PROBABLY": If a meal order isn't ready, then there is a possibility that a soda will be delivered (if the soda isn't part of the food order).<n>- "YES": If the soda is part of the meal already, then it will be served.<n>- "NO": If the meal order isn'r ready, then the soda will not be served.<n><n>##

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:They don't get grades or sit at desks, but crowds of fish do what? Choices:  A: pets B: fills the pond C: attempt to fly D: school together E: breath in water<n><n>### Response:		<n>- A: The crowds of fish is a noun phrase: fish is a noun, and crowds is an adjective. Since the task asks for adjectives, choose D.<n>- B: The noun phrase "fills the pond" describes the noun pond, and not a verb. Choose A, as the options contain only verbs.<n>- C: "To attempt to fly" is a verb phrase that describes a crowd of fish. Choose D, as the task asks for nouns and the options contain only verbal phrases.<n>- D: "To school together" is a verbal phrase, so select B, if you consider it a verb.<n>- E: "To breathe in water" is a verbal noun phrase, so select B as the task asks for adjective phrases.<n>Answer: D: school<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where could you find some airplanes that are not being used? Choices:  A: war B: aircraft carrier C: sky D: graveyard E: crash<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Explaination:<n>### Demonation:<n><n>### Author:Venkatachalam K<n><n>#### Answer: The answer is the aircraft carrier. To answer this question, we'll first look at the options and see if there a non-airplane item in each.<n><n>### First, the war (Option B) would be in use.<n><n>### Next, it's unlikely that the planes in the sky (Option C) would be used for anything else. The crash (Option E) would probably be damaged, which isn't applicable to our question. So, we know 3 of the 5 are definitely out.<n><n>### The graveyard (Option D) could refer to anything from parking to graves, which could only be ruled out (Option E) if they were being used. Additionally, "graves" doesn't seem to fit in the question, such that this one is out of the list, leaving us with the aircraft carrier <n> Answer: C: aircraft carrier<n><n>### Answer: A: the bar (option A).<n><n>### Response To: If someone could find themselves in a room with a bat that might not be able to help them with its wings, what type of room are they likely to be in? Choices: <n>1. A: office 2. B: church 3. C: restaurant D: bar E: prison<n><n>Author: Venkatachalam Khanna<n><n>### Rationale:<n>Option A: office: The most logical place for this bullish baton to be in is probably an office. I'm not super sure, and a lot of logic can be applied to other rooms, but this one just seems to fit.<n><n>Option B: church: I've never quite seen a bat in a church, but I'm sure they have some sort of bats. It might be helpful to some sort of priest. (But this priest might be a mute.)<n><n>Option C: restaurant: Not so crazy, though the bullishness of the baton might not help in a restaurant setting unless in a bull-related event, or even then.<n><n>Option D: bar: This makes the most sense to me, with a bull-raising, bullish baton.<n><n>Option E: Prison
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Long term consumption of beer can lead to all sorts of problems, it can be quite what? Choices:  A: water B: liquid C: foamy D: intoxicating E: harmful<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>The instruction is to write correctly the answer to the given question. The first sentence is, "long term consumption of beer". So we have to choose one word, or phrase, whose meaning matches with the given sentence. The "long term consumption" phrase is an adjective phrase, which modifies the verb "could". The sentence refers to "the consumption of beer", so we need to match it with adjective phrases which are used for the consumption of something. Now, we will examine the given list. The first one is "water", this could be referring to a substance that gets consumed often, but it doesn' t mean consumed in long term. Hence, we can reject "water" as a possible answer as it doesn't match the meaning of the question.<n><n>Next, we have "liquid", this is a possible answer for the question as liquids are consumed in different forms.<n><n>The third one is "foamy", now the sentence refers to beer, and, yes, beer has foam which means there could possibly be foaming in it. But this does not necessarily mean it could cause foaming like the bubbles or foam we see on a coke can or a cappuccino. So this cannot be used as the "beer could cause foaming" sentence in the question and that is why you can reject it as well.<n><n>Next, as far as we have understood "intoxicating" means it could make one's mind clouded, but again how that happens is not known and the sentence refers to "beer". We know that beer doesn't intoxicate one' s mind as much as other drinks like alcohol or whiskey, so we can easily reject "intoxicating" from the list as well.<n><n>And the last option, "harmful", is possible if the beer causes any sort of harm. But here also, we couldn' t find any substance which describes a harmful element in the beer, so this also can be rejected as a possible choice.<n><n>From the above list of the given options, we chose only one option which seems to fit perfectly into the question, the only option we chose is B as "liquid".<n><n>The instruction is: Find out the missing word. Answer: "Long term consumption of bee__"<n><n>### Instructions:Find the missing word.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where does a beaver leave? Choices:  A: wooded area B: body of water C: the ocean D: british columbia E: zoo<n><n>### Response:		<n>I chose C as the answer. In order to do this, I had to go through the options and determine which of them were not correct. One option that was obviously incorrect was A: wooded area because they would not leave that area since their home is there, but the other choices were closer.<n><n>There were three choices that seemed to fit the description of a body of water: a lake, the ocean, and a body of water. In order to solve this choice I eliminated the British Columbia choice because it was not related to the body of water so I crossed that answer off. I then asked myself if it was the lake or the ocean and I chose the ocean choice (choice B) because I think that a beaver would leave the water it is in to explore the land around it rather than vice versa.<n><n>### Input- 1,Ans,Answer:Find the next word in the following sentence:<n>"As you might suspect, the answer is A, but not because the question is asking where I was going after leaving the ________. It's because the question is trying to fool you into missing that the word before it is not the answer to the question. When the question says, "Where would someone find a plumbing store? Choices: A: Walmart" I'm looking for a word that goes in the blank that does not relate to the sentence.<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:A beaver builds structures to block what sort of feature? Choices:  A: books B: zoo C: body of water D: wooded area E: animals<n><n>### Response:		<n>The question states that a beaver builds structures to what type of feature to block. A "feature" could refer to geographical features like mountains or bodies of water. The only option that makes sense that bears that description of what a beaver dam is doing is option C: block a body of water. This, though, is not an option, so to answer the question we can simply eliminate all B and C choices which are not an option. We are left with options A and D.<n><n>### Alternately, we could analyze the individual words and see that the beaver is building something to cover over the body of water. A dam is a structure that will block or cover up a body of water. If beaver were building some feature to block the body of water, it would be called a dam.<n><n>Answer: A: beaver dam<n><n>### Input-Drive to a town about 20 minutes away and call a store called the "5&10" to see if they sell a particular book.<n><n>### Input:- Call a place called the 5&10 to check if they sell the book<n><n>### Instance where the two do not match:<n>**Input: - Call a place called the "5& 10" to check if they sell a particular movie. _ This means that they do not sell a particular movie, rather they sell everything. <n>**Input: Drive to a town about 60 minutes away **Input: Drive to a place called the 60 Minute Town. _This refers to an area, not a store or any particular place. Therefore, it does not require an adverb like "about" in order for it to be a match.  <n><n>### Input and Alternate Input:<n>**Input: Drive the store called the 5 & 10 to see if they sell the book.**     <n>**Alternate Input: Drive the store called 5&10to see if they sell the movie.** <n><n>### Instances where the Instruction matches with neither the input question nor the alternate input question:<n>**Input: Call the place called the 5 &10. <n>**Instruction: Answer the following multiple choice question: <n>Do you think the store called 5 &10 has the book? Choices: <n>A: Yes B: Maybe C: No D: I don't

The question states that the best way to get a good room at a hotel in Miami is to book early.<n>2. The question does not state that "rush" is the correct answer.<n>3. We need to book the hotel first.<n>   - "Wait" - We shouldn't wait because we can already book a room with the information in the question.<n>   - "Act immediately" - We should take action as soon as possible, and that's what this answer is suggesting.<n>4. Hence the answer is "Act immediately."<n>Answer: Act immediately.<n>

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Traders work on the floor of the stock what? Choices:  A: building B: hallway C: table D: exchange E: office<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is Option B. The word floor is used in the following contexts:<n>  - As a part of an address: 2425 Main Street, #408, NY<n>  - In the sentence: The plane had to be evacuated on the floor.<n>  - In the question: Where is the plane?<n>  - In a restaurant: We will meet you on the floor.<n><n>### Difficulty:<n>Bonus points for:<n>  - Knowing that floor can refer to a section of a structure, a type of trading, and other things<n>  - The word floor is used twice<n>  - Recognizing that floor is in the question.<n><n><n>### Input:"Who said that?"<n>Given this information about a conversation:<n>A: "Have you heard the one about the man who walked into a bar?"<n>B: "I have not."<n>A: "Then I'll tell you."<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The sentence 'A:...' contains the words 'A said'. These words are in the past tense, so the word they refer to is what has already happened (these words also indicate the conversation happened before you heard about it). In the context of a conversation, the question 'who's speaking' should be asked before someone else speaks.<n><n>### Rational:<n><n>### Rationale 1:Asking questions before someone else speaks gives you a chance to know who says what. It also gives you context for what comes next.<n>### Rationale<n>### Rationale:<n>So, the first rule is to ask 'who's speaking.'<n>### Rationale #2:<n>Secondly, there is only one way to interpret the answer to the question 'who said that?' This is the person mentioned immediately preceding it that you have not yet heard from. <n><n>### Conclusion:<n>That leaves the person who said the lines 'A: "Have you...?' and 'A: "I have not.' as the person who said the line 'A: "...'<n><n>### Input :The man who put a man on the ___?<n><n>### Demotion:<n>The question asks about a person. The first word in the question is a description of the type of man the answer refers to.<n><n>### Solution:<n>The

Choices:  A: read book B: getting bored C: worry D: singing E: s never comes<n><n>### Response:		If somebody is waiting for the bus, they could read a book. Otherwise, they may get bored, or worry, or sing, or s never comes, depending on the circumstances of the waiting.<n><n>### Rationales: If somebody is waiting for the BS bus, they could read one of the books that the bookshop just shipped or just s newest product, they could be getting bored and watching the clock wait for the s to come, or getting bored and thinking about how they can spend their time more efficiently while waiting, or they could sing a song, or they could worry because the train is over half an hour late. (The last option is a joke, but there are plenty of legitimate reasons to worry while waiting.)<n><n>### Input : Where could you find some shining sunshine? Choices:  T: moon A: stars B: ground C: water fountain D: wall.<n><n>### Response : If you're somewhere where the sun is shining, that's a bit of a contradiction.<n><n>### Input  : If somebody is waiting for something they expect, what might he do? Choices:  B: getting bored, C: never comes, A: read a book, D: do fun stuff<n><n>### Response  : There are lots of things that he could do. Doing fun stuff would be one.<n><n>### Explanations - Categories of answers:<n><n>A. Reading a book:<n><n>If somebody is waiting for something that they want to happen, they might read a book. Otherwise they might get really bored.<n><n>B. Never comes:<n><n>When somebody is waiting for something, they are always expecting that it will come eventually, because they want it to. If it never comes, then something weird is going on.<n><n>C. Getting bored:<n><n>When somebody waits for something, there isn't always going to be interesting things around to do if they're waiting.<n><n>D. Doing fun stuff:<n><n>Whenever people are waiting for something, they can always entertain themselves with little tasks. They can do fun stuff!<n><n>E. Shining sunshine:<n><n>People do a lot of waiting these days. The sun does shine, but we need good ways to get to it.<n><n>### The next response is a challenge question.<n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where could you find an armchair that is used by only a few people? Choices:  A: doctor's office B: hospital C: apartment D: study E: furniture store<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationale: 1. An armchair is a large chair that's comfortable.<n>2. In this question, we're looking for where an armchair is used by only a small number of people.<n>3. Analysing the choices:<n>   - The doctor's office (Option A) is a common place to find armchairs in many offices. But it's not used by only a few.<n>   - The hospital (Option B) might not have armchairs in every room, but it would be used by a lot of patients.<n>   - An apartment (Option C) could certainly have an armchair or two in use by a smaller number of residents.<n>   - The study (Option D) of a single resident could have a single armchair. But this is also likely to be used by only a small group of people. <n>   - The furniture store (Option E) wouldn't necessarily keep armchairs in stock, but would have many people using them in-store. <n>4. The most accurate answer would be the apartment (Option C), since it would have a small number of occupants, many of whom have armchairs.<n>Answers:C

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:How often are secular parties held? Choices:  A: short term B: crowd C: unpredictable D: frequent E: eternal<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer is E: eternal<n>The parties are never crowded or unpredictable and they are also not frequent.<n><n>### Rationales<n><n>The question says "How often are secular Parties held?" and the options provided are : short term, crowd, unpredictable, frequent and eternal.<n><n>From this, we know that there are parties, they are always held and they don't tend to be frequent and are unpredictable.<n><n>We now look at each option in order to find the correct one as it's the first letter of the first option that is correct.<n><n>**short term** - We know that the Parties are always held and are not frequent because there are no other options provided in the question, this leads us to eliminate option A.<n><n>**crowd** - As the parties are often held, it's not unpredictable and it's not possible for them to be frequent, so we don't choose option B.<n><n>**unpredictable** - As the parties often come around every day, they can't be frequent and not be unpredictable which leaves us to eliminate option C.<n><n>**frequent** - The parties are frequent in the sense that they are always held and so it's unpredictable and frequent in the sense that we don't know how often they'll come back. This leads us to not choose option D.<n><n>**Eternal** - Eternal is never frequent but is always held. This satisfies the first letter of the options, so this is the correct answer.<n><n>### Additional Questions<n><n>1. The correct answer choice for the first part of the question is the word "B" because it is on the left-hand side of the line to the right of the question mark in the sentence, and it is also the first word of the sentence. The answer choice for the second part of the question could only be selected if it was on the left-hand of the line to the left of the question mark in th sentence, which it isn't.<n><n>2. It refers to a time in the past when someone was unpopular because they were being mocked.<n><n>3. They are not popular because they aren't a popular band.

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. The owner said that it's not really a Chihuahua. <n>2. We're also given that the owner gave it a snack after it had done something.<n>3. This would mean cat would be an object of the action (in the sentence).<n>5. It would also be awkward to give a'sniff' to the car as a sniff would be the movement of the nose.<n>6. The sentence uses the word'slept through the night and cried a little'. This gives us that the owner had to wake up twice with the dog. <n>7. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:A student wants to hear what the professor is saying, what does he do? Choices:  A: gain experience B: taking notes C: listen carefully D: complete test E: focus<n><n>### Response:		Student might want to listen to what the professor is saying.<n><n>### Input:(1) How would the answer (Student wants to hear what the prof. is saying) be different if it is about a subject-verb agreement issue vs. a plumbing question? (2) Why are these questions different?<n><n>#### Rationales:<n>(1) The student's objective here is what the professor is saying vs. where the plumbing can't be used for relieving a dry throat.<n>In the former, you're asking for something specific, in the latter, a more general location of where the plumbing is but cannot be used for water.<n>(2) These are structurally very different; an answer (as in the second question) about what the professor is saying would have to be a noun phrase, such as "his lecture".<n>The location question about plumbing, on the other hand, would have to have a transitive verb (e.g. "can't use") and an object (e.g. in this case, "plumbing")<n><n>### Input:#40:  Which part of speech would the underlined word be? Choices: A: preposition B: adjective C: noun D: pronoun E: subject<n><n>### Response:#26<n>Answer: Part of speech is either (1) a noun or (2) a pronoun<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: What did you bring on your vacation? Choices: A. a guitar C. a tent B. a camera D. a bathing suit E. a bottle of water<n>Rationales: (1) The student wants to know what they brought with them on vacation. (2) Here we're looking at something they took with them for "travel purposes" that, when brought, was on vacation with them (i.e. "took a vacation with you")<n>(3) Analyzing the options (a guitar, a tent, a camera, etc.), these are not things brought because they were needed for recreational purposes. For example, a guitar would not have been brought because of a musical performance that would take place on vacation.<n>(4) The bottle of water would be the correct answer.<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where would you dispose of a broken icebox? Choices:  A: antique store B: in the graveyard C: kitchen D: junk yard E: ice<n><n>### Response:		<n>The ice box is a common term used to refer to an old-fashioned fridge that uses ice to keep food cold and fresh. Most ice boxes are now obsolete because of the wide use of modern refrigerators today.<n><n>### Deductive Reasoning<n><n>Ice box -> old<n>old -> antique store<n><n>Hence, the ice box can be disposed to an antique store<n><n>### Response 2<n><n>The junkyard is where used things are sent to be resold. There is no proper term for an ice box but an ice box is used as part of a refrigeration system that consists of an icebox, an ice bin and a freezer. Ice box -> Ice<n>Ice ->  Junkyard<n><n>Hence, ice box can be disposing to junkyard.<n><n>### Response with multiple steps<n><n>The refrigeration system needs to cool something to prevent it from spoiling. When the appliance is used, the cold air condenses and accumulates.<n><n>#### Ice box<n><n>The ice boxes were introduced in the late 1800s. It is a device that contains ice to cool things. It consists of an ice box, an ice bin, and a freezer.<n><n>#### Junkyard<n><n>A junkyard is a place where things are kept for reuse and resale.<n><n>Hence, used refrigerators will be sent to a junkyard.<n>

Unpaid actors work for free and this question is asking for a place where this is happening.  <n>2. We can eliminate A(shopping mall) because it doesn't have unpaid workers.  <n>3. We can eliminate D(school) because it has paid staff/unpaid students.  <n>4. We can eliminate B(hospitals) because these types of hospitals have paid staff.  <n>5. We can eliminate E(military base) because even though they may have a military base within it, this base may not be populated and therefore wouldn't have unpaired actors.  <n>6. Choices:  A: grandma B: clothing C: jewelry store D: clothes E: fabric store<n><n>### Response:		<n>C - Clothing store<n>### Explaination:<n>Since you're looking for a specific kind of fabric, the person you ask most likely knows a tailor or a seamstress who might have what you need. Also, you will find lots of other kinds of material besides just what you would use to make a quilt, so you might even make a jacket, or a dress, or a skirt if the tailor has other kinds of material.<n>### <n>### Instruction : I found no candy at the movie theater, so I left empty handed.<n><n>### Response<n><n>So I left empty handed. Why didn't the sentence end here? Because it is very easy to make people sound like they make up stories. If you make sure something didn’t happen, follow it with the word “didn’t”. This tells the reader that it is what you meant and that you also checked on what was happening at the movie theater and found that you didn’t find anything to eat.<n><n>### <n><n>### Instructions:<n>You're tired of waiting on lines. Instead of "Where would be the best place to park near the store?", I would say "Where is a convenient place to park that's not too far from the store?"<n>### <n>The people asked are not supposed to give up a location that has already been sold, so the person isn't able to make a choice about the location where she would go.<n>The explanation is:<n>To make an accurate decision you need all information at hand. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:After bringing eggs home from the store in what are they held? Choices:  A: chicken coop B: supermarket C: box D: egg carton E: henhouse<n><n>### Response:		<n>4. What are you going to bring home?<n>Input: Which is the one word in the passage?Choices:  A: pencil B: eraser C: paper D: book E. pen<n>### Response:The words in the passage are: pencil, eraser, paper, and book<n>5. The phrase the "one word" in the passage probably means which of the following?<n>Input: 3. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:A small dog is lost in New England, where would it likely be found? Choices:  A: own home B: old england C: new hampshire D: coffin E: denmark<n><n>### Response:		The dog is a small dog that was lost in New England. Given that the dog was lost, it may or may not be found in any of those places. Therefore, it may have traveled to other places that may not be included. Based on the question, the dog may be found in a Denmark (Option E) because the dog is a small dog and may be found to be in this other country that is different<n>### Instruction : Answer the multiple choice question based on the information given here<n>### Demonstator : What is the type of plumbing used when transporting oil?<n>### Response:Oil pipelines : It can carry oil but not water<n><n><n>```python<n># A simple 15 line task<n><n>input='Where could you find some plubing that would not be useless to you if you were thirst'<n>for i in range(5):<n>    print '------------'.center(20)<n><n><n><n>if input.lower().startswith('where '):<n>    print'input : '+input.lower()<n><n>if input.endswith('plumbing '):<n>    print input.lower()<n><n>else:<n>    print'None'<n><n>input = 'A small dog is lost on New Englan,were would it likely be found '<n>for i in range (10):<n>    print'-------------'.center(23)<n><n>input1 = 'A small dog'<n>input2 ='lost in New England'<n><n># find the words<n>if input2.strip() in input.lower():<n>    if (input1.strip() in input1.lower()):# and input1.strip ends with 'dog'<n>        if'small' in input or'small dog' in input:<n>            print''+input2+' '<n>answer = ''<n><n>for a in range(8):<n>    answer += input.lower()+'. '<n>print answer.strip()<n>```<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The band enjoyed their success and fans, they loved to what at the start of every concert? Choices:  A: hear crowd go mad B: working hard C: clap D: reproduce E: celebrate<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:<n>This question asks us to identify the band members’ ritual before every concert. And that sounds like exactly what we have to do here.<n><n>Analyzing the options: It's important to keep in mind that if a band enjoys success and fans, that will mean they are well-known, likely popular, maybe famous. It will also likely mean they have an established practice of doing something before each concert. We would need to ask: Did each of the options occur as bands’ practices?<n><n>The answer to that question turns out to be no, unless we allow for the possibility of doing something other than what's specified in the choices. So let's explore the options.<n><n>Option A, “hear crowd go mad” means that bands enjoy it, and they will experience joy whenever their fans become ecstatic. No, not really their ritual, right?<n><n>Option B looks like it could work. After all, music is what bands (generally) play for audiences in concerts. If bands work hard, they will (generally) play music. And that could mean they have some kind of ritual before going on stage, which would resemble working hard. It's not a certainty, but if one option is likely to be true of bands, we want it to be this one.<n><n>Option C looks like something a band would do in the pre-concert ritual. We certainly clap our hands for bands during live show, or while listening to their music, so it fits!<n><n>On the other hand, option D is a little more ambiguous. Would they do a copy (reproduction)? Is that their ritual? Well, what do bands usually do? A variation on that question is: How would this option work as a pre-concert rituals?<n><n>Option E works a lot like Option D, so it’s likely to be an unlikely answer.<n><n>While an argument can be made for one of the three remaining options, it’s still uncertain. Therefore, I’ll go with the one that least strains credulity: Option D: reproduce. The pre-concert ritually may involve reproducing their popular music.<n><n>So, the correct answer is reproduced songs/music (Option D).

Hence the town would probably be a good place to get barbecue sauces.<n>        Answer: A: detroit<n><n>### Rationale:You're trying to find an interesting place for lunch, where should you try? Choices: A: your friends and family E: the office A B C D E<n><n> 	### Rationales: 1) The problem can be modeled as choosing the optimal number that is not 25% of the sum of 3/5 of your salary.<n>2) 50% is in-between 1/3 and 2/3<n><n>3) 50% cannot be the same as or a multiple or multiple of 1/3<n><n>4) 1/3 does not equal 2/3<n>5) 3/5 cannot equal 2/3. <n><n><n>6) If there were a possibility that the employer were to give the employee the same pay as their colleagues, the number would not be 2/3<n>7) Hence, there would have to be a difference between the payment and 1/3 of the sum of 2/3 of the employee's salary, and the other answer is A.<n><n>8) In addition, paying for friends and family could be possible. <n><n>9) Hence, the answer is A, the office.<n><n>Answer: A: the office<n><n>### Instuction:  What type of transportation is fast but does not always require payment? For this reason, it cannot be our answer. <n>
