Choices:  A:"Tenacity is not the act of being determined or stubborn," according to the site<n>B:"Tenacity can be the act of being determined without being stubborn," according to another site<n>C:"Tenacity can mean the act of being determined instead of stubborn," according to yet another site<n>D:"Tenacity can include both the stubbornness and the determination," according to the site above<n>E:"Tenacity has nothing to do with either stubbornness or determination, according to the site"<n><n>### Response:"Tenacity requires being determined."<n><n>### Input"Hard work sometimes leads to great success, according to a dictionary." Choices:  A"Hard work can lead to great success, according the dictionary," but sometimes you can hit a wall<n>B"Hard work sometimes can lead to great success."<n>C"Hard work can't guarantee great success, according to another dictionary."<n>D"Hard work sometimes means that you're not guaranteed great success, according to the same dictionary."<n>E: "Sometimes hard work can't guarantee success, according to the dictionary."<n><n>### Rationales<n>1. It gives the phrase "hard work" and the definition "great success."<n>2. So, this would make success likely, right?<n>3. We're supposed to look for an answer that makes hard work less likely to produce success, so we take this one out.<n>4. If that doesn't satisfy us the first time it could be because we're expecting more for hard work.<n>5. We should examine the other sentences for whether they're specific enough to make it clear that not all hard work will lead to success and take them out if they aren't.<n>6. By doing this we get a clear sentence - "Hard work only sometimes means great success, which seems quite unlikely.<n>### Answer: "Hard work only
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where is a bay always found? Choices:  A: lake B: manhattan C: shoreline D: coastal area E: los angeles<n><n>### Response:		Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Demonstration: <n>Input: Where could a bay always be found? Choices: a) lake b) manhattan c) shoreline d) coastal area e) los angeles<n>Rationales: The word "always" here means that a bay will always be found in its appropriate environment. There are several bay waters surrounding Manhattan, and we consider Manhattan as part of a coastal area or coastline. These are not part of the answer, because a bay will never be found there. A bay will never be found in Los Angeles either for the same reason. So this rules them out as answers. Next, a bay can only be found on a shoreline or a coastal area. But that makes it difficult to distinguish whether a bay is on the shoreline of a lake or a shoreline in a body of water. Thus, a bay can be found in a lake but not on land. In that case, a bay is found in Los Angeles. Conclusively, a bay will never be on land and hence, a bay will always be in a coastal area or a shoreline.<n><n>Answer: coastal area or shoreline<n><n>#### Test run<n><n>### InputWhere is a bay found? Choices: A) lake B) Manhattan C) shoreline D) coastal area E) Los Angeles<n><n>### Response<n><n>The coastal area or shore line is a good answer as they are water areas where bays can be found.<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>The coastal or shoreline cannot be ruled out because they are the only options that can be a bay or on the coastline. <n><n>The other options are on dry land or do not contain any water.<n><n>### Task <n><n>You're a consultant for a technology company based in Cupertino, California. A new system for processing email is the brainchild of a team from the R&D department. <n>One of the features of the system is an automated message filter, which is designed to recognize and send "junk" email into a designated file. There are several types of email that the filter classifies as spam: 1) email containing sexually explicit language, 2) emails containing a single word, (for example, 'yes'), 3) emails containing certain phrases

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The man needed to buy flooring, where was he looking for it? Choices:  A: walmart B: loft C: house D: home depot E: kitchen<n><n>### Response:		<n>I got home depot in this one! This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What could happen to you after you see some beautiful clouds above you? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:When a snake prefers warm, sunny weather, where would it likely want to live? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The man set the cup on the table.  It didn't matter.   He didn't heave anything to put it on, and he lacked the what to balance it? Choices:  A: tenacity B: hands C: coaster D: skill E: breaking<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### #A<n>* There was no "cup on the table" in this sentence.<n><n>* ##(B): The man set the cup [ on the table ]. **It didn't matter.** He didn't have anything to put it on [he had no what ]. He [lacked the skill ].*<n><n>---<n><n>### Instructions:Answer all of these multiple choice questions. Choices: A: Yes B: I'll say A: Yes B: No C: No D: I'll say C: No D: No<n><n>### Response<n>**#A:** There is no logical relationship between the first sentence and the remaining sentences. While it's true that the man set the cup on a table, there's nothing in the remaining choices to suggest that it should affect the outcome.<n><n>**#A: Yes**. But the first sentence was an instruction stating the objective rather than providing content from which conclusions may be gathered upon.<n><n> **#B: No**. "It didn't matter." refers to the man's actions. If the man doesn't care about his actions, then he'll continue on as is.<n><n>---<n><n>**#A**. Weak.<n><n>---<n>**#B**. The question is whether the man will say the cup was atop the table. The cup could have just as easily been set atop the chair behind it as the table itself.<n><n>---<n>#### #A<n>Yes, no, I'll say...<n><n>---<n>##### #A<n>No, yes, I'll say<n><n>---<n>### Instruction.What would an onlooker say happened if she saw the man put a cup on a table and then leave? Choices: 1. Nothing 2. It was put on the table. 3. He just set it there. 4. He set the cup on the chair and left. 5. He set it on the table and left A) 1 B) 2 C) 3 D) 4 E) 5<n><n>### Demostration<n>* 4. He set it on a table and left.<n>* That's the choice given.<n><n>### Response Choices:(B) He didn't set it on anything.<n><n>---<n>## Instructions: Answer all

But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: ignore B: enforce C: authoritarian D: yell at E: avoid<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>In this instance, a response can come in two types: complete, and incomplete.<n><n>- complete: An answer that completes the task.<n>- incomplete: An answer that requires modification to complete the task.<n><n><n>You can either:<n><n>- type in what you think the correct answer is.<n>- copy and paste what you think is the correct answer<n>- or you can copy and paste what you're seeing in the instruction or demonstrate step, then say what it means and what it doesn't mean. <n><n>For example: if the task is to ask a question, and the question is, "What is this?", you could either copy and paste the question or write what you're seeing from the demonstration/instruction then state what it means and what question should be asked.<n><n>You should include:<n><n>- the line(s) you copied and/or pasted from the instruction or demonstrate step.<n>- your reason or rationale<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>An answer that appropriately completes a task is typed into a field below.

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What is it called when you slowly cook using a grill? Choices:  A: backyard B: restaurant C: crockpot D: neighbor's house E: barbeque<n><n>### Response:		<n>A restaurant's outdoor grilling area would be called *backyard* (Option B). Barbequeing (Option E) is cooking food over an open fire or by using smoke and the residual heat.<n><n>### Input-Rationales:<n>* Crockpot: An electronic cooker with a heating element that can be set to cook for a long time.<n>* Neighbor's house: Possibly a fire pit?<n>* Restaurant: Grill could be an area of the backyard or other outside area.<n>* Barbeque: The act of preparing and baking on an open fire or by a smoking and residual heat.<n>* Backyard: Possibly a fireplace or bar-b-que? In the backyard.<n><n>### Answer:<n>B: backyard<n><n>### Instructions A task description that requires you to define your position in terms of the topic in question. Below is another task description that requires a response that completes the task.<n><n>### Task description:<n>Write a response that appropriately describes your view of the subject in terms of the description above.<n><n>### Response for demonstration:<n>My view of the subject is a little contradicting to your question because I feel that in a way, the question is a bit vague, and in a way it is vague.  The first option, *backyard* really is not the correct term for outdoor grilling. *Crock pot* should not have even been an option, and what they mean by *grilling*, I think, is like smoking meat.  What people really mean by *being outside* is they mean *barbequing*  when they mean something specific.  What you are describing to me is grilling, and it doesn't always have to be outside.  I have an indoor grill with a grill tray and a grill rack.  Sometimes I like to barbeque inside, because it can be toxic outside.  In Hawaii we are always exposed to smoke from the volcanoes and we cannot stand it all the time.  It gets in our lungs and makes me sick.  So, I prefer to cook inside.<n><n>### My thoughts on the subject:<n>The second paragraph of the article, *When is outdoor grilling the best cooking method?*, goes into

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What does playing soccer for a long time lead to? Choices:  A: excitement B: fatigue C: anger D: hurting E: getting tired<n><n>### Response:		Explanation of your chosen answer.<n><n>### Input Actions and outputs:<n>  - This is asking what playing soccer for a period of time will lead to.<n>  - A: excitement- The game is fun, you would be excited to play.<n>  - B: fatigue- You feel tired from playing<n>  - C: anger- You may feel angry towards someone on your team<n>  - D: hurting- Your legs or arms may hurt from soccer<n>  - E: getting tired- you get tired playing<n>  - Hence the answer has to be E (Option E)<n>  - Answer: E: getting tired<n>

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: near B: closeness C: here D: proximity E: this<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:1. The question asks what type of sensor the expert was explaining the sensor uses as part of the system. In this case, he said it was a proximity sensor.<n>2. The words "proximity" and "proximity sensor" are synonymous, and they both refer to something like a distance sensor. They are not interchangeable. The "this" in the third sentence is likely referring to the word "proximity."<n>3. Analyz:<n>   - Closeness (Option C) refers to a similar concept as near, but one that is not necessarily geographic. This excludes the other answers.<n>   - Here (Option D) refers to the general subject, not the particular object discussed in the question.<n>   - This (Answer E) refers to the word "proxymity," hence the answer is proximity.<n>Answer: E: proximity<n><n>### Input The sensors would just sense the distance then set off the alarm, the installation expert explain it was called<n><n>### Response Instruction<n>Input: The sensor would just sense the distance, then set off the alarm. The first part could be describing another part of the system; this part is describing the sensor itself, which is a noun.<n><n>The installation expert explained it was as [a] what kind of sensor?, which is the sentence's question.<n><n>2. The only correct response is [proxymity], as indicated by the word [that], which points to a noun.<n>3. Analysing the options:<n><n><n>### Ratelene:1:The expert explain that the sensor was a near sensor<n><n>### Response Choice; A:<n><n>Answer: A: a proximity sensor<n><n>### <n>###<n><n>### 1:The sensors should just the [the sensor would just the distance set off an alarm the installation expert explained<n><n>### Rationele:<n><n><n>## Rationale 1:<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where would you see some people doing jumping jacks? Choices:  A: military base B: opera C: water fountain D: bus stop E: church<n><n>### Response:		Choices have two categories: military and religious institutions. Jumping jacks are not a military exercise and the others are.<n><n>Answer: A: church<n><n>## Solution<n><n>```python<n>def solution(instruction):<n>    instruction = int(instruction)<n>    answer = get_answer(instruction)<n>```<n><n>```python<n>from typing import Dict<n><n>RATIONALE_CHOICES = {<n>    'A': 'The Answer is an area of study, a subject of research, or something you do all the time,  such as studying or practicing.',<n>    'B': 'The Answer is something that a teacher assigns to you or that you do when asked.',<n>    'C': 'The Answer is one of the choices you have when it comes to making a choice or choice of things.',<n>    'D': 'The Answer is a good quality that helps you understand or explain something.',<n>    'E': 'The Answer is what you say you think or feel when asked.',<n>}<n><n>RESPONSE_DIGGER = {<n>    '1': '1: Choose an Answer.',<n>    '2': '2: Answers.',<n>    '3': 'The three most common Answers are A, B, and C.',<n>    '4': 'The four most popular Answers are A, F, and I.',<n>    '5': '5: Answers.', <n>    '6': '6: Choose an Answer to choose from all Answers.',<n>}<n>  <n>def get_answer(instructions: int) -> str:<n>        digger = [RATIONALE_DECIPHER for rationale_dict in RATIONALE_CHOINCES][RESPONSE_DECIPHER]<n><n>        instruction = digger[instructions]<n>        choices = [x for x in choice_diggers for x in DIGGER_DECIPHER][instructions]<n><n>        while choices!= '':<n>            response = 'Choose an  {}{}'.format(choice_diggers,digger)<n>            print(response)<n>            while True:<n>                choice_str = input("Choose from: ") <n>                if type(choice_str) == str:<n>                    choice_str
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where is there usually a fiddle playing? Choices:  A: music store B: dance hall C: orchestra D: symphony E: tennessee<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: the music store<n>The fiddle in the music store is played for its intended purpose.<n><n>### InputWhere can you usually get the most bouncing? Choices: <n>1. A: the beach <n>2. B: a trampoline<n>3. C: a wall <n>4. D: a door <n>5. E: a bed <n>Rationales:<n>1. The word "bouncing" can be taken literally to mean "a great deal of bouncing", where bouncing is an action you'd do in a bouncy place.<n>2. Thus, B says "the trampoline", implying that many bounces occur there.<n>3. Bouncing is an action, so the place of the action matters as well. <n>4. A door can't be the right choice as it would lead to a great bump, but not bouncing<n>5. A bed can also be used for bouncing, but is not used as a trampoline.<n>Analyse the options:<n>1. A Beach (Option 1): while there may be some gentle bouncing (a bounce), there is usually no bouncing activity. <n>2. A Trampoline (Option 2): is the most obvious choice based on Bouncing and what it does in general.<n>3. A Wall (Option 3): A wall can be used to bounce off of, but it cannot absorb the energy, which means it wouldn't bounce.<n>4. A Bed (Option 5): can also be used to bounce, but there's a lack of a hard surface to bounce on.<n>5. At home (Option E): would typically be used for sleeping.<n>Rationales:
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What do drugs do? Choices:  A: damage B: cloud mind C: lower i.q D: cause illness E: cause accidents<n><n>### Response:		<n>This question was asked as a fill-in-the-blank<n><n>Rationales: (1). You can figure out what the choices are because the question reads "do drugs do".<n>So the question means "What do drugs do?" There are five choices - "D", "E", "C", "B" and "A", so we have to pick one of them as the best choice for what "do drugs do."<n>(2). There's no context clues in the question that help you eliminate options, so we have to rule out the options using rules from the question.<n>(3). For "cause illness", it doesn't matter which drugs are used.<n>(4). Rule out option "the" drugs in "A", which would cause too big of illness to fit the question.<n>(5). For "do" in "how do drugs do" (how the question reads), we have to pick the option that sounds like it can be used in the past.<n>(6). For "cause accident," you have to use the past tense of "cause accident," so it has to be "caused an accident," not "causing accident."<n>(7). So the answer is "caused disease" because it meets all those requirements.<n>Answer: Caused disease<n>

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Can you name a good reason for attending school? Choices:  A: get smart B: boredom C: colds and flu D: taking tests E: spend time<n><n>### Response:		Can you name a good reason to attend school other than learning? The only choices provided that have nothing to do with education are colds and flu (which aren't reasons for attending school and may be reasons to skip or avoid school at the direction of a doctor), and spend time (which can be done anywhere, but specifically is not done in school other than in classes).<n><n>### Instructions:In an equation, the first term (called the constant) is always represented by the number one. The second (called the coefficient) goes only through zero. If n is a number greater than zero, then the number n times another number is the first term. (In other words, it is the coefficient of y.)<n><n>### Demostration:5 * 25 = 125<n><n>### Task:24x24x24<n><n>### Input:(number * number * number) * number<n><n>### Response:(number * (number * (number *... * number)))<n>(24 * 24 * 25 * 25) * 25<n><n>## Exam Problem 1<n>(1) If $100 was invested at 7%, compounded quarterly for 8 years, then what was the value of the investment?<n><n>The function of compound interest says that a 7 percent interest rate over 20 years = 2.4 percent per year, compounded four times a year.<n>(Round to the nearest $50.)<n><n>### Solution<n>100 x 1.07(1.07(0.024)⁴ ) = 20475.55<n><n>### Exam Problem 2<n>(2) If $10 was invested at an interest rate of 6%, compounded monthly for 13 months, then how much would this be worth?<n><n>We will start by taking 10 and applying the rule that the rate times the principal equals the interest compounded the number of times.<n><n>$6\%x10 = 0.6*$10<n><n>We will solve this by plugging in the values and simplifying<n><n>$0.6*(10) = 6<n><n>To solve for x we will multiply both sides by $0.01 and solve once more<n><n>$0.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where would you see people in uniform playing with a ball? Choices:  A: hole B: television C: sporting goods store D: pool table E: sporting event<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: E sporting Event: 1. They could be playing sports anywhere.<n>2. Choosing from the choices:<n>   - Hole (Option A) refers to different kinds of holes, such as the holes in the walls in which a door would be, or holes in a building where equipment is stored, for instance. <n>   - Television (Option B) is a device on which programs are played. This doesn't mean they are necessarily playing sports on the television, so it cannot be ruled out.<n>   - The Sporting Goods Store (Option C) would surely have balls available for sale, and employees might play with them. However, customers may also come in, see a ball, and play with that, then leave.<n>   - Pool Table (Option D) has people playing with a table called a pool table, but that doesn't necessarily have to do with sports. Additionally, playing pool doesn't necessarily require a ball, unless you use a cue stick.<n>   - The sporting event (Option E) is where people gather to watch sporting events.<n>3. So, given these considerations, an appropriate response would be the sporting event (Option D) because it definitely has the balls and the people that would be playing with them.<n><n>### Inputs:Where would you find some plants that would not be useful as a building material? Choices: 1. A: swimming pool 2. B: oil refinery 3. C: water fountain 4. D: show 5. E: building material store<n><n>### Response<n>You answer: 5. D: building material store <n>### Rationale Answer: 5. D building material store <n><n>### Input Choices: 1) A swimming pool 2) B oil refinery 1. A swimming pool <n>### Rationales: 1) Choice A refers to a place where people play with water, and this doesn't necessarily have anything to do with using water as a building material, so it cannot be chosen.  <n>2) Choice B refers to oil refineries, but these do not have to do with water, so this cannot be chosen either.  <n>3) Choice C is likely a misnomer, and is not referring to a place where you can take water from and use it. Hence, none of

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:He was receiving workman's compensation, he had tripped over a metal rod while building where? Choices:  A: factory B: construction site C: engine D: insides of skyscraper's walls E: shops<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1. The options include construction sites, factories, and shops. The question asks about metal rods that the character tripped over so the answer must be in a place that contains those rods.<n><n>2. The factory (Option B) is a place where metals are made, but not necessarily the tools necessary for construction.<n><n>3. Similarly, the construction site (Option C) is a place where tools and metals are used for construction, but doesn't necessarily store the tools.<n><n>4. The engine of a skyscraper' may contain metals but not necessarily tools for construction.<n><n>5. The interiors of a skyscrape's wall do not typically contain building tools.<n><n>6. The shops or shopping malls (Option E) may have tools used for renovations or construction but it's not common. Thus, the answer will be D: the inside of a skyscraple's walls, as it is the only option that fits the description of the question and the given conditions.<n><n>7. Hence, answer will be D: inside of a skyscrapers walls

Talk to someone in authority<n><n>### Response :  **D**<n><n>> There is no need to hit a student who is not obeying the rules. Choices: A: water fountain B: fridge C: wall D: oil refinery E: banana tree<n><n>### Response<n>The simplest answer is water fountain, even though it's not exactly true. But why would you even expect to find an orange at a fountain? And why would D be the best choice for water fountain? It doesn't make sense.<n><n>Anyway, it's going to be E. B is too short to be water, even though oil refineries aren't exactly long. C and D have the word fountain (although you could argue it's figurative). A doesn't apply at all. E and F are the only options with actual fruits in them.

Choices:  A: increased energy B: healthier C: loose skin D: beauty E: death<n><n>### Response:		<n>You can also use the 'answer' function to generate an answer.<n><n>```javascript<n>answer('You can also use the answer() function to generate an answer:<n>  answer(['What is a good result' +<n> 'of losing weight? ']);<n>  <n>  var output = document.getElementById('output');<n>  <n>  for (let i = 0; i < answer.length; i++) {<n>    let temp = answer[i];<n>    temp = temp.toUpperCase();<n>    temp = temp + '.';<n>    output.innerHTML += temp;<n>  }<n>  <n>  output.innerHTML += '<br><br><br><input type="radio" name="answer" value="b"> A. <n>                       <br><br><br>'; //create a radio button object to represent choice A. (see answer code)<n>  output.innerHTML = 'B. <br><br><input id="mychoice" type="radio" name='answer' value="b' checked>  C. <br><br><n>                    <input id="mychoice2" type="radio" '+ 'name="answer" value="c' + '/><n>                    <br> <br>');<n><n>  output.innerHTML+= 'D. <br><br>';<n>  for (let j = 0; j < answer.length - 3; j++) {<n>    output.innerHTML+= 'E. <br><n>                        ';<n>  }<n>  output.innerHTML+='<p><input type="radiobutton" checked style="display:none" name="answer" class="mybtn">B<n>    </p><n>    ';<n>  console.log(answer);<n>});<n>```<n><n><n>The code above will render the choices as the question would as you choose them. <n><n>After you have an answer choose you can check the code.<n><n>### Input<n><n>```javascript<n>//use this line of code to pass your choices array to the answer function.<n>let choice = ['What is a good result'+<n>  'of losing weight? '];<n>let result = answer(choice);```<n><n>### Output<n><n>```javascript<n><p id="output"><n>B.<n><input type="radio" id="mychoice" name="answer"value="b"<n><n>```<n><n>### Bon

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The accountant used a calculator regularly, he kept one at home and one at the what? Choices:  A: desk drawer B: desktop C: office D: wristwatch E: city hall<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: A: desk dra<n><n>### Rationale:<n>This question is asking us, based on the prompt, where a calculator is used.<n><n>The options presented are:<n>- Desk Drawer: The answer is a location where an everyday device is stored. "The Answer is a location where an everday device is stored". So, we can quickly conclude that this would never be an answer option.<n>- Desktop: The use of the option "desktop" suggests that we're looking for where an office employee would keep his/her everyday device (i.e. a calculator) if he had to. Also, the "everday device" would never be left lying around in this location. This suggests that this would never be the answer.<n>- Office: As above, we're looking to select a location where an every day device could be kept if the need were to arise. Also, we are explicitly looking for the location where an office employee keeps his calculator if he had to. As above, we can say that this is not the answer.<n>- City Hall: Well, this location does not seem useful for the description of "an everday use calculator".<n>- Wristwatch: We have not been given any information as to why somebody would carry a wristwatch. This makes this answer even less of a possibility.<n><n>The only remaining option is, indeed, the desk drawer

Choices: A: I do not know B: 200,000 C: There are a lot of books<n><n>### Demostration:<n>The library is a collection of books.<n><n>### Diffictionary:(adverb) a lot:used for describing the amount of something that a person believes is a lot or a lot to say that something is very large or many or too much <n><n>### Differenciate:<n>There are a lot of books, There are many books, There are a lot many books<n><n><n>### Instructions:"What is your name and age?"  Choices: A.My name B.My name is  C.My name is  + age D.You are old<n><n>### Demestration:<n>(A. My name is  + age)<n>The answer to the question is incorrect. This sentence has the proper form.<n><n>### Definitions:(article- noun ): an indefinite pronoun, the, a, an<n><n>### Explain:<n>(A. is) are used as a subject<n>(A. is + name) is used as an appositive or adjective<n>Answer: A. My name is (age)<n><n>### Instructio:What is a good way to begin each response for the following paragraph?<n><n>> Write a response that appropriatly completes each request, and explain why your response is the best answer.<n><n>### Paragraph:The first three days are not so bad. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:If you're speaking to a lawyer about getting a divorce, what relationship status are you trying to end? Choices:  A: being married B: sisters C: marriage D: two people E: lawyer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Rationales:1. If there's a question where you speak about ending a certain relationship status, it can be sure that you will have a divorce from a lawyer, the relationship was a marriage.<n>2. Since if you speak about ending a relationship, you will necessarily have to be single or not married. You will need a lawyer for this type of process of marriage, so choice D is the correct answer. The choice of the answer in this question is completely determined by the options. You need to get a divorce or speak to a lawyer about divorce, where you are trying to end a relationship with your wife. Then there is marriage.<n><n>```python<n># coding=utf-8<n><n>def demo_task2():<n>    import fileinput                    #import required library file<n>    #with open('task_2.txt','r') as f<n>    #with open("test.txt", 'r') as f<n><n>    for lines in fileinput.input():            # fileinput reads one or more files from the command<n>    # with fileinput.input([file_name]) # the command line or path to the file given<n>        #if line.startswith("Question:"):<n>        #    print(line, end='')<n>        <n>        if line.strip() == "Demogrphic":<n>            print("\n=============== Demogrphic============\n----------Question: Answer with your name-------------\n\n\n")<n>            print("\nChoices:(A,B,C,D,E,) \n\n\n", end='')<n>            print("I am Demogrphic.")<n>        elif line.strip() == "[Ending of Question] \n":<n>            pass<n>        else:<n>            print(line, end="")<n><n><n><n>def demo_func():<n>    # input() takes a string<n>    # print(input(), end="")<n>    # input() is a built-in function, so it's case-sensitive.<n>    # raw_input() is not case sensitive<n>    # input("What is your name? ") would input("What is your NAME? ")<n>    <n>    x=input("What is your name: ") #ask question like<n>    y=0 #variable x<n>    <n><n>    print("Let's calculate using Python.")<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:WHat leads to someone's death when they are very depressed? Choices:  A: suicide B: overdosing C: sadness D: murder E: cyanide<n><n>### Response:		<n>A: Suicide is defined by Merriam Webster as `the act of killing yourself voluntarily and intentionally especially by a person who is experiencing despair or depression`. As such, this would result in their death when they are very sad (the condition of depression is very sad in and of itself).<n><n>Answer: A: suicide<n><n>### Input：When did Walt Disney move to California? Choices: 1923 B 1933 C 1943 D 1953 E 1963<n><n>### Response：<n>A: he moved to California in 1923 (10 years before he was born).<n><n>Answer: 1922:https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Walt_Disney<n><n>### Input<n><n>Answer: A) 1953<n><n>Disney's film company moved to Burbank in 1939, when his brother Roy joined as partner. (Disney moved out in 1966.)<n><n>Disneyland opened in 1955.<n><n>Answer: The first Disneyland came about in 1953. Walt Disney died in 1965, so he could not have moved there.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Who is likely yo have a caring heart? Choices: 1. A: school ground B: zoo C: grocery store D: police station E: home<n>Rationales:1. The question asks for a place where two people could play hide and seek, not one.2. Analyzing for the options:<n>   A: school ground(Option A) -- Probably not the best place to play hide and seek, given the other students and teachers.<n>   B: zoo(Option B) -- The animals at most zoos are locked up within their enclosures, so they wouldn't be hiding.<n>   C: grocery(Option C) -- Most grocery stores have too many people going in and out of them to do hide and seek, even if it's allowed.<n>   D: police station(Option D) -- There's too many staff there, and it's a crime to hide.<n>   E: home(Option E) -- Definitely acceptable.<n>   A: home --The answer here is obviously a home(Option E). However, you would probably want to play around outside with it for a change, and if you did then the choices would be reversed.<n>###Input (multiple):<n>Where could your parents get a great deal on their insurance? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What will happen to skin pinched in something? Choices:  A: feel cold B: feel pressure C: feel bumpy D: itches E: feel clammy<n><n>### Response:		<n>For this problem, the only answer that doesn't satisfy this request will be "b", so this can be the only answer. Note that "c", "d", and "e" are incorrect. Since skin pinched in something should make the skin feel cold, pressure and bumpy have nothing to do with what it feels like. Additionally, it should have nothing to do with burning or itching, which are both dealt with as "D", burning or itching when skin is hot. Skin should only feel clammy if the skin is stuck to something. As the question doesn't specify on where the skin is pinched, it shouldn't be clammy just as a result.<n><n>### Input::<n>How many seconds in six months?<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Let's figure this out. We know that 6 months = 6*30 days = 180 days. Everyday has 24 hours, so multiply 180 by 24 and we get 4320 hours, where each hour has 60 seconds. Now we add all the seconds and it yields 257,600 seconds.<n><n>### Answer: B: 257,000 seconds.<n>

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. In that case, the<n>implied answer could be C "make reservations" or E "sleep".<n><n>Choice C - I think this could be taken as "applaud" with an implied "the actors and<n>directors".<n><n>Choice D - The question states that the crowds stood and did something else.<n><n>Choice E - This doesn't really make sense given that the play was apparently so<n>popular with the crowds that they decided to stand, I would assume they would<n>actually experience the play.<n><n>Rationale:<n>Choice A - Appeared to be grammatically correct and I did not find anything wrong<n>with the sentence, so I would say A is the answer to the question.<n><n>Answer: C - make reservations<n><n>### Input : If the question is for a single question only, what is the name for two or more questions?<n>### Demonation :<n>Input: If the question is for single question only, what would be the name for multiple questions at a time?<n>Rationals: 1. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where do you put a new dining table? Choices:  A: cafeteria B: arranging papers C: in the park D: formal dining room E: house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The question asks you where to put a new dining room table.<n>2. This is an open-ended question, which means you have to answer it with your own thoughts.<n>3. Analizing the options:<n>   Option A - The Cafeteria is where we get our meals from, and we don't put our new dining room table there.<n>   Option B - We don't store our documents there either, so we definitely don't put our dining room table there either.<n>   Option C - We can definitely put our table in the park; it's a great place to enjoy the fresh air, and we can put a table there in addition to chairs, barbecues, and tables to enjoy our meals outdoors.<n>   Option D - The Dining Room is where we have our meals, so we're definitely not going there.<n>   Option E - Our house is where we live in, and it has plenty of room for furniture.<n>4. Hence it is correct to put the table in the park (Option C), otherwise, the option D is the best choice to put the table.<n>Answer: C: in the park<n><n>### Write your own instructions:<n><n>1. What is 'plumbing'?<n>`plumbing` is the system of pipes, water tanks, and other appliances in a building, used for transporting water and maintaining a level of pressure in order to supply hot water to a building at all times. `pluming` doesn't have anything to do with potable water.<n>2. Where did the above instruction come from?<n>The instruction came from an official website. There was an exercise for a test that is provided by a website.<n>3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where would someone learn to play an upright piano? Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where would you be able to hear a bassoon played in an unpleasing fashion? Choices:  A: orchestra B: baritone woodwind sound C: symphony D: play music E: high school band<n><n>### Response:		<n>Rationales:1.The question asks where someone could hear bassoon music not played in a pleasing fashion.<n>2.This means we're looking to play bassoon music not played properly.<n>3.Analyzing the options:   - Orchestra (Option A) is the most likely place to hear bassoon music. Even if such music was played improperly, it should still be relatively well played since it's going to be the main focus of the orchestra, in which case an otherwise good performance is more likely to be marred by a horrible bassoon solo or two.<n>   - Baritone wooden sound (Option B) might be a place where one can hear a bassoon played poorly, though it would probably be part of an ensemble and not a large, solo concert. But even then, bassoon solos would likely be fairly well played even when performed poorly.<n>   - Symphony (Option C) would generally be a large orchestra where, if someone was playing a bassoon in such a way that the performance is poor to untrained ears, such performance would stand out more.<n>   - A play (Option D) would be a more improbable setting for a bassoon solo. One might hear a bassoon in a play, but if the performance is poor, it would likely be part of an ensemble, as this would be more likely with an accompanying orchestra.<n>   - A high school band (Option E) would be a pretty unlikely choice to hear bassoon misplayed. This is an environment where even the nonprofessionals are still fairly good and would probably not cause such music to stand out too much.<n>4. Hence the answer is orchestra (Option A) as a bassoon is probably the most likely to be misplayed and cause the most displeasure.<n>Answer: A| Orchestra<n><n><n>

Choices:  A: lead to laughter B: love C: laughter D: smiles E: tears<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>#### Explanation 1:<n><n>We asked for a pathway a feeling of happiness could fall into.<n><n>We are looking for something happiness does fall into.<n><n>Considering the choices, options B, and C, both of these feel like they would include laughter, but B has the added word love. Love is not a feeling of happiness, and neither does happiness naturally make people laugh, so option A is the correct choice.<n><n>#### Explanations 2:<n><n>A feeling is a state of mind. A feeling is not an action, so falling is not possible. Therefore, any answer to this problem would not be grammatically correct.<n><n>#### Examples of incorrect answers:<n><n>* "Lead to laughter could fall into one person feeling happy."<n>* "Laughter leads a person feeling happy to fall."<n><n>### Instructions:<n>When the dog needs to see where it is going, it has to look up. What other way does the dog have to know its location?<n><n>### Explanation 1<n><n>When the dog needs go somewhere, it has to look down at where it is going. While looking down, the dog needs to look up and around it, so it can detect any obstacles.<n><n>### Examples of incorrect answers<n><n>* "The dog knows what its location is when it is looking."<n><n>### Input<n>Which of the following can tell the location of a building?<n><n>### Response<n>Considering a satellite image and a photograph, a satellite image is better at telling the location of a building.<n>### Explanations<n>This was an easy one, because the answer was right there in the question.<n><n>## References<n><n>```<n>1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_image<n>2. http://www.education.com/academics/grade-school-activities/satellite-images/<n>```<n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:If your watching television and accomplish nothing what have you done? Choices:  A: getting fat B: get fat C: typing words D: falling asleep E: wasted time<n><n>### Response:		The most appropriate response is: Option D: FALLing asleep<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The phrase "accomplish nothing" suggests that the task of watching television is not of any value.<n>2. "Getting fat" (Option B) is obviously what the word "nothing" is doing.<n>3. "Typing words" (Option C) would not make sense. Television is a visual medium, and typing words is only for audio-only mediums.<n>4. "Wasting time" (Option E) wouldn't make sense, as if the task were accomplishing something, it wouldn't be considered wasting time.<n>5. Hence, "Falling asleep" (Option D) is the correct answer, because if you accomplish nothing while watching TV, you must be sleeping.  <n>Answer: D: FALLing <n><n>### Input : What are the chances of using something over again to complete a task? Choices: <n>    <n>    25: The more often you practice something, the more likely it is to be successful the next time.<n>    26: It depends on the task and on your skill at that task.<n>    35: It depends on the value you place on that task.<n>    40: What is the task?<n>    50: This question is too difficult, and therefore pointless.<n>    60: It should be relatively high.<n>    75: It depends on you and how good you are at doing that task.<n>Rationales: All answers are technically correct, but only answers #1 and 3 are actually useful answers, hence, the correct answer is choice #1.<n><n>### Input 2:What kind of job would you be qualified for if you are a student and have a certain amount of money? Choices: 1: Doctor<n>15: Engineer<n>30: Truck Drivers<n>55: Janitor<n>85: CEO / Presdient/ VP<n>Rationales: It depends on what student you are (undergrad/graduate/professional?) and what you have (a certain amount of money or a large amount of money?)<n><n>### Inputs:If you are going to be doing something after leaving your house, what could you be going to do if you are going to an ice cream store?<n>1

Choices:  A: container B: supermarket C: pantry D: sandwich E: jar<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Your answer choice:container<n><n>### Your rationale:<n>Plastic food tubs would be a bad choice of containers for storing peanut butter unless they are sealed and there's a lid to help prevent the spread of the peanut butter. In case they were not sealed, then I would opt for the pantry since it is dry and shelves, or the sandwich.<n><n>### Explain response:<n><n>### How your decision process:<n>I first started by eliminating the jar option since the jar cannot be kept upright to allow the butter to easily pour from it, besides making it inconvenient to use.<n>I then eliminated the supermarket and water fountain since while they are good places to buy peanut butter, they wouldn't be good places to store it.<n>I also eliminated the container and the pantry since while the container would be a good container to store the peanut buttter, its not as convenient as a pantry shelf.

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. (Rationale)<n><n>### Input:[John went to the store to buy some groceries. He wanted some apples, and asked the owner what the cheapest price was. He then asked how to tell how old the groceries were, and the owner replied by saying that the sign said best before.] Choices:  A. 3 months ago B. 3 weeks ago C. Before the year D. This week E. 5 years ago<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instructions:<n>* (C) Before the year<n><n>### Rating:<n><n>* (C) The answer is from this weeks best before date to this months best before date. (Rationale) [Note: "best before" and "best if used before" are usually used interchangeably and are synonyms.] (Rationale)<n>* (C) There may be several dates on the box. They are each for different things, but they will be close together. (Rationale) The groceries can't be older than they were yesterday. (Rationale) (Rationale) [Since the question asks specifically about "grocery" then we can assume that the products will all be the same "best before" date (or have a similar date) and will be from a store (in this case, John asked about what items to buy and the store owner replied he could sell apples, so we can assume they are from a typical grocery store.)] (Rationale) [As you can see they don't really have to be the best but they do have to be in the same day. They have to be "before" the year or before when they were "best by" meaning they have to have come out less than 12 months ago or they wouldn't be considered "best." (Rationale) You can't call them "good until" like you have to do with eggs in the U.S., eggs in America need to be "sell by", not "best by." For example, you would have two months of validity in this case, assuming the products were "best by" November 2022. (

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:When you plant a garden you can harvest what to eat? Choices:  A: flower B: animal C: flower petals D: vegetable E: alive<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question asks about what you can harvest when you plant a garden. An option must be given that would be harvested from plants growing in a garden.<n>2. The options are:<n>   - Flowers as a whole (Option A) are not actually a 'thing' you could harvest from a garden. They are grown to produce a pleasing aesthetic effect.<n>   - Animals (Option B) are not typically harvested, like vegetables might be.<n>   - Flower petals (Option C) can be used to make tea, and sometimes other products, so that would be an appropriate choice to harvest.<n>   - Vegetables (Option D) can be grown in a garden and then harvested in order to make food out of them. That's what is asked about here.<n>   - Alive (Option E) is vague, and doesn't really reflect that you're specifically harvesting from a plant. But otherwise, it might be accepted as an answer, since plants are living and they're grown in soils that you could harvest.<n>3. Therefore, the answer is flower petals (Option C). <n>Answer: C: flower petals<n>### Response:You could not eat the vegetable, you could only eat the flower petals.  <n>Answer: C: Flower petals<n>

This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: michigan B: wyoming C: mississippi D: tennessee E: mississippi<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>Answer: C: mississippi<n>**Rationales:** 1. The question gives you the clues that Jackson is a popular last name.<n>2. The word "governor's office" is a hint that the name-place-things answer is a city.<n>3. The options:<n>   - Michigan (Option A) is a state, not a city.<n>   - Wyoming (Option B) has the wrong abbreviation as there there's no state named "wyom".<n>   - Mississippi (Option D) has a governor's office, but not in Jackson.<n>   - Tennessee (Option E) has a governor'ss office, but doesn't have this name.<n>4. Hence the only city with a governor's's office and a name like Jackson is mississippi.<n><n>Answer: C Misssipi<n><n><n>### Input:"You can only find one thing in common between two people named John. What could that be?" Choices: A: last B: initial C: hair type D: zodiac sign E: birthday<n><n>### Response:"One is the last name and the other is hair type, hair type is the common factor between two people named John."<n><n>### Rationales:<n><n>1. The question asks what could all John's have in common, and the only thing listed would be last names.<n>2. The options:<n>3. A. Last B. Initial C. hair type D. Zodiac sign E. Birthday<n>4. This means that all John's's have a last name, which is their common factor.<n>5. This means that one is the last name.<n><n>Answer: One is the last name (John)<n>

Choices:  A: ohio B: washington state C: alaska D: canada E: flowers<n><n>### Response:		D: Canada<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input:Though nearby,<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. Though nearby, means that the items being referred to are either in the same house or that they are nearby in the sense of geography.<n>2. There would be an imported product if there was such a thing in one country and it was being transported to the other.<n>3. However, an imported product refers to a product that was made somewhere else, whereas the apple is from one of the states of the USA.<n>4. Hence option D, Canada is the one that will work as the US gets a lot of fruits from Canada which would mean that the apple from the apple tree would be an imported product.<n><n>Answer: D: Canada<n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Eating breakfast in bed can make you feel what, assuming that you don't spill anything? Choices:  A: vomiting B: pleasure C: happiness D: contentment E: mess<n><n>### Response:		<n>```javascript<n>const plumbing = (choice) => {<n>  let option_A = "C"<n>  switch(choice) {<n>    case A:<n>      option_A = "E"<n>      break;<n>    case B:<n>      option_B = "E"<n>    default:break;<n>  }<n>  return option_A<n>}<n>```
