This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The judge did not take this part of the job lightly, the man was guilty but it was his passing sentence that condemned the man to what? Choices:  A: go to jail B: incarceration C: intercourse D: death E: judgement<n><n>### Response:		<n>The judge who did not take this part lightly was passing sentence on the man for murder. Incarceration would simply mean that the man had served time, but not been released. The sentence would have been condemnation, which would imply death. Intercourse and judgment were not valid choices.<n><n>### Question:What is the common name for the plant commonly known as the snake plant?<n><n>### Answer:<n>The snake plant is also known as the Saint George's sword, mother-in-law's tongue, or Devil's tongue.<n><n><n>### Output :The following sentence is a fragment.<n><n>### Input :My best friend is my best friend.<n>### Output :No,  My best friend is my friend, which makes me happy to call her my best friend.<n><n>### Solution :<n>My best friend is my friend which makes me happy to also call her my best friend<n><n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:While laid up in the hospital she tried remembering good times, like that massage on vacation that brought great what? Choices:  A: dream B: knowing C: depression D: pleasure E: nostalgia<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. The question asks about a time in the past when she was on vacation, and how that vacation was a happy time for her.<n>2. I remembered that: [1](https://openstax.org/books/biology/pages/13-1-the-structure-of-the-nucleus-p100) 3. Analyzing choices (A to D):<n>   - (A) This refers to a dream, not to something in the real world. (B) “knowing” cannot be a plural form of the noun “thing”, so we can eliminate this.<n>   - “depression” is not necessarily an emotion, but it can refer to a state of the person. So, we can eliminate this. (C) This is incorrect because “pleasure” refers to a good time, not to nostalgia (which also can't be plural). (E) “nostalgia” can refer to fond memories of past events [1, 2, 3](https://encyclopedia.com/social-sciences-and-law/sociology-and-social-reform/social-issues-social-problems/nostalgia), so we can eliminate this as well.<n>3. The answer can be (D) “pleasure” as it refers to having a good time on vacation.<n>[1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pleasure) [2](http://www.dictionary.com/browse/pleasure) [3](https://ency.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Nostalgia&oldid=871947483)

Choices:  <p> “We should use a wrench when it is appropriate”<n>    <p> “We always use a wrench”<n>    <p “We must use a screwdriver when it is necessary”<n><n>### Rationales<n>1. The correct answer is that “We must use a hammer when we should use a wrench” is a special case of the statement “We should use a hammer when it is appropriate”. <n><n>2. The second option is the mirror image of the first option, so it isn't the answer.<n><n>3. Neither the third option nor the fourth option is true:<n>  - When should you use a screwdriver instead of a wrench? If you're screwing something together or fixing something on a screw basis, you'd use a screwdriver, not a wrench. (And obviously a wrench when it's a nut kind of problem.)<n>4. The only option that makes sense is the first one, which says that you should use a hammar when you could use a wrench, because the second option is the reverse of that statement. It makes perfect sense if you re-read it, which is why I'm pretty sure the statement should be: “The statement: ‘We should use a wrench when it is appropriate’, is a special case of ‘Use a wrench when you shoud use a hammer’.”<n>

If you assume that "years of playing" means that a person has been playing for a long time, then if "tennis elbow" doesn't occur, then the only result could be "pro".<n><n>## 308. I feel good when I exercise. So I exercise.<n>**Input**<n>This sentence suggests that<n><n>### 1. I feel good when.<n>### 2. I exercise.<n>> This sentence describes someone who exercises and also feels happy at the same time.<n>> You're only left with the option that is logical and consistent with the given choices: I exercise.<n><br><n><n>## 319. They had been studying all afternoon.<n>**Input** <n><n>### Democracy:<n>The answer is: been studying all afternoon. Because it makes more sense considering the two sentences.<n><n>### 319. I had been studying all afternoon<n><n>### Demons:<n>I would also choose "been studying all afternoon" since for it to make sense, the sentence has to make some sense. I can only assume that it's been studying all evening.<n>The second choice "I had been studying all afternoon" makes sense but doesn't have the same meaning. To answer this, it depends on the choice of the 3rd sentence.<n><n>If the sentence reads: "I had just left the library all afternoon", then choosing the first option is appropriate.<n><n>If the 3rd sentence reads "Then I got invited to tea with my friend the next day", the sentence makes little sense, and I would not be able to answer the question correctly.<n><n>### Answer:<n>I believe I made a correct choice, so it is the first choice. I wasn't able to understand the sentence at hand. I am unsure what I am missing.<n><n>### My guess is that this sentence is used to describe someone who just left the library. You can only choose between the first or second choice. The first choice is better.<n>

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. Choices:  A: restaurant B: basement C: all buildings D: carpet E: synagogue<n><n>### Response:		The basement, pertains to the holy rooms (Option B) inside the temple. This is because in a temple, all places are holy except the ones for menstruating and eating, which are in the basement [source](https://www.answers.com/Q/In+a+temple+of+the+Jewish+faith+who+can+go+in?page=1&src=2#:~:text=Anyone%20may%20enter%20a%20temple,outside%20the%20men's%20and%20women's%20sections.)<n><n>### Inputs:Where was the first movie, starring Bugs Bunny, made? Choices: A: the beach B: inside a cave C: out on the desert floor D: under a bridge<n><n>### Response and rationales:The place where a film is made has to be big enough to shoot filming.  A movie shot inside a cave might need too much lighting, which needs to be filtered so as not to affect the cave’s natural environment. Similarly films made on beaches might encounter unfavourable weather conditions causing them to postpone filming or delay production.<n>Hence, the answer is the desert floor (Option D).<n><n>### Instructions: What is the name of the type of shuttle (that is not named an SRB) used to propel a rocket into space? Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Many addicts turn to exercise to deal with their addictions, this is because it is a healthy way to do what? Choices:  A: condition heart B: expend energy C: laugh D: stretch E: weigh<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Input: Many addicts turn to aerobic exercise to deal with their alcoholism, this is because it works as a healthy way of what? Choices: A: stretching B: strengthening C: relaxing D: releasing endorphins E: burning calories<n>Rationales:<n>1. The question asks many addicts turn to ________to deal with their alcohol addiction.<n>2. Since the alcoholics are addicted to alcohol, aerobic exercise doesn't satisfy those addictions. It would only satisfy other addictions, and this one does not say what kind of addiction the alcoholics have.<n>3. Analysing the options:<n>    - A: stretching does not really mean to stretch muscles by itself (though it could be used as well).<n>    - There could be other types of exercising that could work, depending on what addiction the alcohol addicts have.<n>    - B: Strengthening muscles does not necessarily mean to deal with alcohol addicts, it could make other types of addicts.<n>    - C: Relaxing doesn't mean that those alcoholics are addicts in alcohol, so this would not help.<n>    - D: Endorphins are chemicals that are released during exercise with intense activities.<n>    - E: burning calories could indicate an addiction to fast food.<n>4. Hence aerobic exercise is out, the best choice is D: releasing ________.<n>Answer: D: releasing<n>---<n><n>### Ex:1)<n>Demonstration:<n>The correct answer is B.<n><n>1. ____:<n>    - A. 13<n>    - B. 12<n>    - C. 10<n>    - D. 22<n>2. This will serve as the foundation of your response.<n>* Response: You will need to choose one of the following: (1) In the form of a question with a short answer, (2) In the form of factual question, (3) In the form of multiple choice, (4) In the form of matching, (5) In the form of short answer with an explanation. <n><n>### Input Choices (1):<n>Option: A: In the form of a factual question with a short answer in which you provide a simple response<n><n>### Response Choices (1): <n>Option B: In the form of fact.<n><n>### Input Conclusion:<n>* Explanation of choices A and B: You will be able to choose either response as you must always respond to the question. <n><n>1. There are many different types of questions, though. They can be in a question form with a short response, or a one word answer, or a question with a factual response, a multiple choice response, a matching response, or a short answer response that explains the answer.<n>2. These various question responses will be used in different scenarios. You'd need to go with option B.<n>- Giving is a verb, and the question asks what.<n>- The word life is in the question, not just reproducing but new LIFE.<n>- Birth is a noun and is the correct choice.<n>- Everything else is either a verb (giving), noun (new life), adjective (fun), or a preposition + noun (propagation).<n><n>A: Reproduction, the creation new life, begins and end with birth giving new life. Not sure if you could take the noun "propagation," but the rest of those have already been ruled out.<n>B: reproduction, creation of new life

Choices:  A: dream dreams B: think critically C: cross road D: drink coffee E: drive a car<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: Drive a car (D) is the correct answer for the question "what can you do to feel more alert if you're sleepy?"<n><n>### Explanation:<n>1. The question asks what a sleepy human can do to feel more alert.<n>2. Analyzing the statement given, you need to think of an action the subject (sleepy human) can take to feel more alert, and it must actually work in reality to feel more alert. So we are essentially trying to find something real you do to get a buzz if you're feeling sleepy.<n><n>3. If you drink coffee (Option E) this definitely puts you on alert, you just might be jittery or caffeine-addicted.<n><n>4. If a human is driving (Option D), they might be on edge to drive well, especially in some countries with poor traffic enforcement. This at least puts them in a position to make a lot of decisions or quick responses to what's happening in traffic, which can be good for keeping you alert instead of tired.<n><n>5. A sleeper may even dream (Option B) all sorts of things to wake up. This might keep them alert while they're resting, but they will likely feel jittery when they awaken.<n><n>6. While a sophisticated human might think critically (Option C) about all his or her options, this will most likely not be very effective way to feel less sleepy.<n><n>7. Lastly, there is nothing in the given information or our analysis that says a human being might cross a road (Option A) to feel more alert. We don't need to put them in danger to be alert, we just need to make sure they stay awake.<n><n>### Input : Would the presence of blood increase the price of a used car? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where might I find unusual varieties of roses? Choices:  A: botanic garden B: flower garden C: backyard D: supermarket E: outdoors<n><n>### Response:		<n>  A: botanic gardens might possibly have some interesting (not so ordinary) varieties of roses you might not find in typical gardens. These roses could include wild and old varieties.<n>  D: a supermarket is unlikely to sell only unusual roses.<n>  - It is possible that the roses sold might be unusual, but then, what makes them peculiar? They'd appear oddly uncommon in the typical settings of botanic gardens. So, you're much likely to find most of the usual roses in these gardens.<n>  Answer: A: botanic garden<n><n>### Conclusion:<n>Here are a few facts to learn about how to write good responses.<n>- Read the question carefully.<n>  It's very important that you answer what's asked.<n>  The question is about unusual varieties, so answer accordingly. Don't answer about the supermarket.<n>  Read this question carefully.<n>  The question asks about a place where you might possibly find unusual varieties of rose(s).<n>  The question uses the phrase'might possibly', which is a hint that you might think of alternatives to options(A) and (B).<n>  You might possibly find unusual varietie(s) of roses in a botanic garden (Option A) because there are more types of roses planted there.<n>- In many cases, there might be numerous options from which to answer a test.<n>  You have to choose one appropriate or correct option.<n>  For instance, the question does not expect you to name all possible options.<n>  You have a single choice in the question.<n>  You just name the option to which only one answer is reasonable.<n>  In the above question, the options A or C are best answers to the question, because there are not numerous choices.<n>  So, you select the option that best describes the subject of the question.<n>- For example, if a question asks 'What color is the car in the picture below?', then do not<n>  'answer' gray because it's another common color that people might mistake for green.<n>  Remember the question wants you to accurately and correctly answer, and not wrongly and mistakenly<n>  choose an answer.<n><n><n>### Next Steps<n>1. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Sam found a giant hole in the plain.  What might this hole be called? Choices:  A: hill B: gorge C: sandplain D: cliff E: mountain<n><n>### Response:		<n>A<n>---<n><n>### Input : Sam thought they were in Alaska (option B), where there's lots of glaciers (option A) and lots of tundra (option C). <n><n>### Response :<n><n>### Input A: Sam thought Alaska (option B) was a cold (option E) and windy (option D) place. <n><n>### Input B: Sam thought they were near their cabin (option A). <n><n>## Input C: Sam could hardly see the sunrise (option E).  <n><n>### Response  :<n>Option E seems the most suitable, but it's not in the list,so the answer would be A: Sam thought they were in a warm (option D), snowy (option C), and windy location (option E).<n><n>## Input : C: They thought the weather was good (option A), and it was the end of summer (option C), so there were lots of apples and pears (option E). But they had to start walking again (Option B), and the only thing they had to eat was peaches (option E), and none of them were ripe (option E).<n>### Response: <n>Option E is the only response that makes sense,because the last part said that the only fruits available from their trip was peach,but they were not ripe.<n>Also the weather was good and it was the end on summer,so it's probably not winter.<n><n>## Input : B: They thought it was the end of April (option A), but it's too cold to sleep outdoors (option C) so they made camp on a hill (option E).<n>They thought the weather was terrible (option E). They had to start walking again, and it was too late in the season to get to the cabin before it got dark.<n>### Response<n>It's still cold but it's not winter,it's april, not november. So the option would be C  : They made camp on a hill, which it said that, so that it would be option C<n>###  Response :<n><n>## Input : <n>They thought the weather sucked (option E).<n>It was the end of April, so it was probably not winter. <n>They thought the cabin was way too far (option E).<n>The only thing they
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:After going for run you have a sense of what? Choices:  A: satisfaction B: flying C: sweating D: falling down E: trip<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>After going for a run, you have a sense of __[______________]{a sense of}.__<n><n>### Rationale:<n>1. The question describes a "sense of" after going on a run.<n>2. We have to decide what the "it" is that "you have a sense of."<n>3. Analyzed options:  <n> - A and B are "what" questions. We're not trying to answer what, so they are out.<n> - D and E are also "what" questions.<n> - Only one "what" type question (Option C) remains.<n><n>### Output:<n><n>A: satisfaction<n><n>### Instructions:Now, put each sentence in the correct order. In all cases, the word in parentheses represents text that is outside the sentence:<n><n>1. After going for a run I have a sense of satisfaction.<n>2. As soon as (you go) I have a sense of what.<n>3. The more I exercise the more I sweat.<n>After going for a _______________ (you), I have a _______________ of satisfaction.<n><n>### Answers:<n><n>1. As soon as you go for a run, I have a sense of ________________ (satisfaction).<n><n>2. The more I _______________ (exercise), the more I sweat<n><n>### Instrument:How does this compare with your intuitions?:<n><n>### A brief explanation of this test using the following definitions may be helpful:<n><n>### Expectancy: How strongly does something feel to you? For instance, how much do you like orange juice before putting the orange juice in your mouth? How does that juice feel in your mouth?
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What will you need to do to decide whether to be seeing artifacts? Choices:  A: learning B: painful memories C: thinking D: awe inspiring E: pleasure<n><n>### Response:		<n>#### A.<n>You will learn by experiencing the artifacts to see them. In other words, you will learn by doing to see the artifact.<n><n>#### B.<n>You will have to undergo painful memories. You remember something to see them.<n><n>#### C.<n>You will have a learning process which takes the form of thinking about them to see them.<n>It needs an effort to see things, it's like a cognitive processing.<n><n>#### D.<n>Thinking about your awe-inspiring experience which involves a learning process can help you to see them.<n>You will have an emotional response that can help you to see the artifacts. You will learn to be more open-minded to see the artifact as result.<n><n>#### E.<n>You will learn to undergo unpleasant experience for thinking about something.<n>You will learn something to see it.<n><n>Answer: A: learning<n><n>### Input : What is a good way to see a good thing? Choices:  a. feeling b. looking c. not seeing d. having a thought e. feeling something<n><n>### Response<n>#### A.<n>Feeling: if you can feel something, you know that it is good.<n><n>#### B..<n>You will need to look at what is it in order to see a good thing.<n><n>####C.<n>A good thing is not seen by itself<n><n>#### D. <n>Thinking something is good, you can have a good idea<n><n>#### E. <n>I feel something to know where something is.<n>If you know where something is, you can see if it is good.<n>

But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: bookstore B: library C: doctor D: home E: table<n><n>### Response:		<n>There are a variety of places where one might store magazines, but the most common places are the bookstore and library.<n><n>1. Bookstore: People often keep magazines at the bookstore not only when doing research, but when purchasing as well.<n>2. Library: Libraries often have magazines in which a wide variety of topics are covered.<n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:A person takes a seat to watch a movie, where is he? Choices:  A: in cinema B: at the park C: martorell D: jeep E: airplane<n><n>### Response:		<n>1. A person who is trying to find an airplane takes a seat to watch the film. Hence, the answer we're looking for is jeep (Option E).<n>**Hint:** The question asks a person takes a seat to see a movie, where could he be?<n><n>2. Then, we have two conditions (A) cinema and (D) martorell, where the person could not be.<n>3. To eliminate the choices, we can start by eliminating all those in which the film is shown. Hence, the choices that could not be used are cinema and jeep.<n>4. To rule out park as a choice, we can simply take note that the question doesn't specify any park, hence it could be anywhere. Since jeep is the only thing left, the answer must be jeep.<n>**Hint:** Analyzing all the choices, we conclude that an airplane is only located in jeep.
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:James lived in the top of a tall tower.  He could see clouds when he looked out his window.  Where might he live? Choices:  A: in books B: radio station C: city D: tower E: medieval castle<n><n>### Response:		A: in books<n><n>-----------------------------------><n><p align = "center"><img width = "400" height =<n>"400"<n><n><n>src="https://github.com/Vik1031/Vk1031-Resume/blob/master/images/exercises/images/10th%20edition/1%20of%205%20exercises/112/image1.png"<n>/></p><n><n><n>----------------------------------<n><n>-------------><n><p align="center"><img width="500" height="500"<n><n> src="https://github.co/Vik1021/Vik1063-Resume/blob//master/images/exercise/113_exercises/image3.png"/></p><n><n>   - Explanation:<n>     1. If James lives on top of the tower, he might be able to see clouds.<n>     2. Hence, the clouds might imply he lives in books (Option A), or a radio station (Option B), or a tower (Option D).<n>     3. A city (Option C) or a medieval castle (Option E) probably wouldn't have clouds at the top of buildings, since they're typically surrounded by other buildings that affect the weather.<n>     4. Hence, the options that make sense are: (i) books, (ii) a radio station, (iii) a tower, and (iv) a city.<n>     5. Hence, the option we're looking for is a tower, which is (Option D).<n><n>Answer: A: in books<n><n>### Instructions:Solve each of the exercises below.<n><n>### Input 1. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:A musician is most likely to perform a concerto for clarinet with what type of group? Choices:  A: music store B: orchestra C: jazz band D: rock band E: music studio<n><n>### Response:		<n>We can distinguish types of groupings as:<n>1. Music Store - A Musician does not play in the music store<n>2. Orchestra - A musician can play in an orchestra<n>3. Jazz Band - A musician can be in a Jazz Band.<n>4. Rock band- A musician cannot play in the rock band<n>5. Music Studio - A musician performs in a Music Studio<n><n>### Answer:<n>We can conclude as an orchestra (Option C) or a jazz band (Option D); they can both be music studios and they have both of the musician types.<n><n>### Input : What did Christopher Columbus discover during his second voyage to North America? Choices: 1: Mexico 2: Canada 3: West Coast 4: South East<n><n>### Response :<n>This question makes us think of two types of discoveries: one being a country, and the other being a direction on a map.<n><n>* 1: Christopher Columbus discovered Mexico during his second voyage to America<n>* 2: Christopher Columbus did not discover Canada during his second trip to America<n>* 3: Christopher Columbus did discover a part of America during his second trip to the Americas, but didn’t discover the entire continent (e.g. it’s still unknown for sure what else he found).<n>* 4: Christopher Columbus did explore America during his second voyage in America, with a focus being on the West coast.<n><n>### Answer :<n>It would be the west coast (Option 4).<n>

Choices:  A: india B: hole C: cage D: habitat E: rain forest<n><n>### Response:		<n>We will be seeing this question as a demonstration.<n>We will not see the answer for now.<n><n>### Input from teacher: Where could you find a lemur? (Multiple Choice) A: India B: hole C: Cage D: Habitat E: Rain forest Rationales: 1: The question asks where a lemur can be found.<n>2: Lemurs are animals. Since they are not humans, they could not be found in India.<n>3: Analyzing the options-<n>   - India (Option A) is not a suitable place; it's not the type of environment for lemurs to live in.<n>   - The hole (Option B) refers to a hollow in something, possibly a tree. This seems unusual, unless there's a hole in a house where a lemur has moved in. However, that's not the type.<n>   - The cage (Option C) is not something suitable to hold lemurs.<n>   - The habitat (Option D) is correct because it describes a type of environment where it could be found, such as in a rain forest.<n>   - No rain forests (Option E)<n><n>4: Hence, the answer is habitat (Option D), as the question asks for the appropriate place-habitat.<n>Answer: D: Habitat.<n><n>### Conclusion

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Turkey is a nation in what part of the world? Choices:  A: middle east B: asia minor C: asia D: provide meat E: balkan peninsula<n><n>### Response:		<n>Turkey is in Europe. The question asked what country Turkey is in, so we're looking for what country is in the region indicated by the choices.<n>1. The question asks what country Turkey is in (Option A), so we'll exclude answers that don't address country.<n>2. Choices (Option B) and (Option C) are regions and include many countries, so excluding them would lead to a set too small to use for choosing.<n>3. Let's eliminate Choice (Option D) (provide meat) which is not a country. (Option E) (Asia minor) can be excluded as all countries included fall outside the Turkish borders.<n>4. So the answer is that Turkey is located in the country (Option B) (Asia minor).<n><n>Answer: Turkey is a nation in Asia minor<n><n>### Input:-A country is __________. Choices: A: country of people B: country with people C: nation D: nation of people E: nation where people make citizens.<n>Rationales:1. As a result:-A country is country with people.<n><n>4. <n><n>### Input:\-Was Benjamin Franklin founding father of the United States of America? So for Franklin to be the founding father of the Unted States, the response must be 'yes' (Choice A), so the answer is that 'yes' is the answer.<n><n><n>Input:\-Is the answer no, yes, yes or no? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Johnny and bill fought over money.  Johnny wanted it to be over.  What might he choose to do? Choices:  A: control people B: settle everything C: buy food D: increase power E: kill bill<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Reference:<n><n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What is likely to happen to someone's speech after becoming inebriated? Choices:  A: regret B: automobile accidents C: drunk driving D: talking nonsense E: talk intelligently<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: What is likely to happen to some one's speech after becoming intoxicated?<n>Response: D: they're likely to begin talking nonsense<n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. One of the definitions of intoxicated is to render an individual unable to distinguish what is real from what is imagined.<n>2. After the point where you could reasonably use the term 'drunken' (i.e., where a person is intoxicated), they are likely to be less inhibited, which would cause them to talk nonsense. Hence, the answer would be "talk nonsense."<n>3. Alternatively, it might be reasonable to pick 'talk intelligently,' since the inebriated person would be less inhibited. However, the inebriation would render the person likely to be misinformed, which is a form of nonsense.<n>4. Hence 'talk nonsense' is the correct answer.<n><n><n>### Question:<n>What could be the likely outcome of a discussion on the merits and demerits of cages, between a wild animal defender and a hunter?<n><n>### Answer<n>Wild animal defender: I'm going to talk about the merits and de merits of cages first. Choices:  A: opened B: closed C: found at shower D: falling down E: locked<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input: The new kitten hadn' t gotten used to what _ it was allowed to climbing on in most rooms.<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. The question is asking for a verb.<n>2. This verb will modify 'what' to mean what _ something. <n><n>3. Analysing the choices:<n>* 1. Closed (Option A): Doesn't mean what; a choice used to indicate a closed option.<n>* 2. Found at shower (Option B): Doesn't answer what was used to; a choice of "found" is a word that's not used to or modifies what; we could substitute "that".<n>* 3. Falling down (Option C): Doesn't say what _ what; it refers to a general noun.<n>* 4. Locked (Option D): This answers what (the door), and it's an action that happens to a door so as not to apply to what; we could substitute a different choice to convey this information (such as "kept" or "left").<n>* 5. Opened (Option E): This does not answer 'what' used to do; we'd replace it with another answer in its place.<n><n>Answer: B: Closed<n><n>### Input:"That was a bumper crop of tomatoes!". But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: cupboard B: countertop C: water D: hardware department E: england<n><n>### Response:		<n>* Choice A: If the teakettle is something you put drinking water in, then the cupboard is likely a good place to keep it.<n>* Choice B: A countertop is a likely place to keep a teakettles as it's used to boil and serve drinking water.<n>* Choice C: While water is used in a teakettle, hardware department (Choice E) likely doesn't sell them.<n>* Choice D: While England is a country, and Englanders would likely use a kettle to boil water, hardware stores are likely a better place to keep it. The teakettle would be more likely to be kept in that location to serve drinking water to customers.<n>Answer: Choice A: cupboard<n><n>### Instructions: What is the word that is both the name of a state and a word that ends in t?<n>### Demonstraion:<n>Choices: A: Washington B: Oregon C: California D: Alaska E: Arizona<n>Rationales: Answer: Choice A: Washington, as it's abbreviation is 'WA' and they start with 'W', but end with 'A' like the word 'Alaska', which ends in 'As,' but begins with 'Al'.<n><n>### Input : What would you want if you were out camping and it started raining and you wanted to bring out your tent? Tents would probably be placed outside to avoid the rain, since many people prefer to avoid being outside in the rain as much as possible.<n>- Tents themselves are made out of fabric, which can also be used for shelter (though not the same experience as a tent).<n>- Food would be needed, but not for immediate use. You should probably still eat it, however.<n>- The camping gear would include tents, food, and water.<n>- Light is not needed to pitch a tent, since you're probably doing it at night. Though if during the day it helps, that would probably be useful.<n>- A tarp isn't exactly needed for pitching tents, but is also on the camp

Currently, the project does the following steps:<n><n>- Load the text into the network as inputs<n>- Pass the input through a network to produce the output<n>- Compare the output to the target answer<n>- If the answer differs from zero, then the text is output and added to a file<n><n>### Output<n><n>The project stores the text and a 0-1 output in a file that is then used as training data with an updated network.<n><n>### Pre-requisites<n><n>You'll need to do the following to set up the project correctly:<n><n>* `pip install -r requirements.txt`<n><n><n>### Installing<n><n>Clone the project into the folder where the instructions are located and then move into that folder.<n><n>* `./download_data.sh` - Downloads a bunch of training data from the Internet<n>* `./train_model.py` - Uses the newly downloaded data to train a model<n>* `./evaluate_test.sh` - Compares the trained model to some additional training data that isn't present in the original data<n><n><n>### Running the Test Project<n><n>* `python3 run.py` - Runs the output text through the model. The project will print the text to be output and the resulting output in a terminal<n><n><n>### Results<n><n>As can be seen from the tables below, the project generally performs about as well as it can with the text available to it.<n><n>### Prediction Rate<n><n>| Answer | Prediction |<n>|----|----|<n>| A | 0.573 |<n>| B | 0.637 |<n>| C

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Parents often yell in times of chaos, what are they trying to do? Choices:  A: guide children B: understand children C: control children D: care for children E: vent anger<n><n>### Response:		<n>Input:Parents often yel atimes of chaos, what they are trying to d?<n>AnswerA<n><n>### Input Parents often yel in times of chaos what they're do to<n><n>### Response<n>Parents yell when they can't think and aren't calm and composed<n><n>### Input You get to choose an activity and choose a room. <n>### Response You go to room at ground level<n>

Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What feeling might propel one to instituting civil action? It could refer to any of the steps of the court case process, not just the trial.<n>  - Hence, Trial (Option D) is the most specific in this instance.<n>Answer: D: Trial<n><n>### Instructions: Complete the following instructional statement.<n><n>### Input statement: Write a response that answers the following multiple choice question about an instructable statement:<n><n>### Demonsattion:

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:John hated mosquitoes.  It wasn't the bloodsucking that he disliked, it was that the insects made what? Choices:  A: fly B: buzz C: move D: honey E: help flowers pollenate<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>John hated mosquitos.  He believed they made it difficult for him to enjoy his beer garden.<n><n><n>### Rationales:<n>1. The question asks John what he hated about mosquitos, and it is incorrect to assume that John disliked the blood-sucking.<n>2. The answer must follow a set of logic:<n>   - John hated mosquitos since he said "it wasn't the blood sucking that he dis-liked"<n>   - Mosquitos do suck blood:  That's how they get through life!<n>   - Hence, the answer is that mosquitos make it difficult for someone to enjoy their beer gardens.<n>   - Hence, John's answer is that mosquitoes make it difficult to enjoy his beer gardens!<n>   - The bee flies (Option B) make them buzz.  This is incorrect because John didn't say it "wasn't that it made them buzz that he disliked." <n>   - John hates mosquitos because of their movement (Option C), but he didn't say it wasn't that, he said it wasn't the blood-suck.  Hence the answer is something to help flowers pollinate (Option D), since flowers pollenate through bees and bees buzz.<n>   - Honey is produced by bees (Option E) and the honey is a substance that John dislikes, hence John does not like bees because they make honey.<n>   - And hence the answer is that mosqutios move to help flowers pollin-ate.<n>   - Since mosquitos are also made of blood, the question is likely based on the fact that mosquitos help pollinate flowers.<n>3. Hence the answer is "that mosquitos help flowers pollinate".<n><n>### Demostration:<n>Insects and flowers help pollinate one another to continue the cycle of plant life. The flower is used as a pollination tool, and the mosquito carries the pollen from plant to plant through its anatomy.<n><n>#### Rationales:<n><n>1. Insects and flowers help to pollinate one another. They will be attracted to other flowers through aroma, light, and shape.

Hence the answer is, option E: help people<n><n>### Task:<n>  - Input: <n><n>  - Question:How many people in the United States work at sea? How many people work more than a mile away from where they live? How many people work at home?<n><n>  - Demonstration: <n><n>  ## #Option A<n>  #Input<n>  ## The United States<n>  ## Population of the United States: 330 million<n>  ## Number of people who work at sea:<n>  ## 1.4 million<n>  #Rationales<n>  ## Calculation:<n>  ## 330 million/(1.4 million = 241.25 years and 58.75 weeks to fill all jobs for one year at sea), which is equal to 241.3 weeks to fill all the jobs.<n>  ## Or, 58.7 days (241.3 ÷ 4), which is equal to about 12 weeks.<n>  ## To be filled, the jobs at sea would take **around 12 weeks** to fill.<n>  ## Which is around **5** months to fill all the jobs at sea.<n>  ## <n>  ## ## # Option B<n>  ## Input<n>  ## The United State<n>  ## Population of The United State: 330,000,000<n>  ## Number of working women in the united state:<n>  ## 88,000<n><n>  ## Rationales<n>  ## Percentage of the population =<n><n>  ## ## %of popu=88,00/330,0<n>  ## %of popu =2.5949636508883753<n>  ## %of women working would equal 2.549963652594355144%<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:She'd sooner just spray herself with water than the what she didn't like the smell of? Therefore, our body would not be sleeping.<n>    - Kidneys (Option C): Only work as filtration when our blood is flowing. Thus, could not happen while sleeping.<n>    – Muscles (Option D): Only work when we are awake.<n>    –  Mind (Option E): The most reasonable answer is the one that works for the given situation. Choices:  A. The dog is hungry B. The dog wants to play C. Someone is at the dog's home D. The dog is lonely E. The dog is in fear<n><n>Rationales<n>1. In the question, "a person's dog is" barking.<n>2. "the 'dog' refers to the owner's dog. <n>3. "barking" can be due to the following reasons;<n>   - The dog is hungry: If the dog has not eaten, it may bark to signal it is hungry. In this case, the answer would be A.<n>   - The dog wants to play: dogs often bark to signal they want to play and the answer could be B.<n>   - Someone is at the person's home: the dog may bark because someone has arrived at the owner's home, and the answer could be D.<n>   - The owner is lonely: the owner may leave the dog at home alone, which could make the dog bark, and the answer could also be D.<n>    <n>### Discuss:<n><n>### Discourse Question:<n>If a house is being put up, what is most likely going on in that house?<n><n>### Answer:<n>Building<n><n>### Justification:<n>In the question, we have the prefix "up", which means in the air or ascending. We also have the suffix '-put', which denotes a building activity such as building a home. Given the context, the answer has to be A – building a house.<n>

But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: show B: theatre C: hockey game D: movies E: event<n><n>### Response:		The answer is the event (Option A). All the other options do not involve the audience screaming, yelling, shouting, etc. The answer is not the game (Option B). A hockey game would have fans cheering, but they won’t be yelling to each other to be heard. It would also not be the event (Option C). The event is about the performers, not the attendees. It would not be the movie (Option D). The movies have only occasional “ooh!” and “ahh!” and wouldn’t be described as someone screaming. It would also not the show (Option E). The show is about the performers being seen not heard by the audience.<n>### Correct Answer: A: event<n><n>## Example<n><n>Instruction:<n><n>* Consider the list of items below and choose the appropriate answer.<n><n>* Demonstration: <n><n>Input: Which of their siblings is more likely to pick their nose? Analysing the options:<n><n>  - One could assume that the oldest of the siblings could be the more likely to pick their head, since that would mean that the other siblings may have been copying them.<n><n>  - The youngest of the siblings may not know how to pick their head since they are relatively young or too young to know how.<n><n>  - Neither of the two could be most likely to pick their head.<n><n>4. Hence, it's more likely that the baby brother is the more likely to pick his head.<n><n>Correct Answer: E: The baby brother<n><n><n><n>## Example<n>

Choices:  A: countryside B: united states C: beach D: atlas E: developed land<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>- They chose the highway that cuts through the United States.<n><n>### Answer:<n>Answer: B: United States<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>* You are writing a response that appropriately selects the answer to the question below. Write one well-developed paragraph that discusses your answer.<n>* To the best of your knowledge, if you take one of the following routes to get home late one evening, which route will get you home the quickest?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>It took me a little over an hour to get home after work. I live in Los Angeles so getting traffic isn't a problem. Instead of taking the highway for about 45 minutes, my best bet is the route along the beach: for this reason, I decided to take the beach route instead.<n><n>### Rationale<n><n>There are a series of options: the direct one and the one via the beach. It's the latter which will get you home the fastest because it gives you the option of riding your bike instead of having to sit in traffic.<n><n>### Option 1<n><n>I took the direct route as advised, instead of going along the beach. In addition, I spent quite a long time in front of a red light that left me worried I might miss out on the train. If I would take the beach route instead, I wouldn't have as many traffic issues. So for this, I recommend taking the highway.<n><n>### I need to take your survey.<n><n>- You are in a position where you need to write a response that appropriately provides you.<n>- This means that you're answering the questions in a way that will help you figure out why a certain word or phrase is incorrect and why a certain choice is correct. It's not a question of whether an answer is better than another; it's a question of how you're figuring out which answer is correct and which one is incorrect.<n>- There are two options to do so:<n><n>- You could try to list all the ways a word or phrase is incorrect, with a little rationale.<n>- You could try and provide a quick list of everything wrong with the phrase, with a little more explanation.<n><n>### Input<n><n>In my experience, writing a response that appropriates a given statement can be quite difficult for those with no experience in this area. Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:You are seeking to provide yourself what when you're applying for a job? Choices: 1: feathers<n>2: the clouds 3. straw 4: an octopus 5. a pig   Rationale:<n>1) The wind moves the feathers when blowing.<n>2) The clouds do not move when they are blown by the wind, as they are still and are constantly being blown by the wind.<n>3) The same does not apply to straws. When the wind starts blowing, the straws will start moving. Hence, "The wind blows its feathers" can be used as the answer option.<n>4) Although Octopuses can use their eyes to look, they cannot see the world with their eyes. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Choices:  A: tie shoelace B: rest C: tiredness D: run longer E: sit down<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer: None of these<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>* Explain how you completed the task.<n>* If you missed a question, explain what you thought the answer was and why the answer doesn't match the question or vice versa.<n><n>### Input 2:<n>How was your experience with the instructions?<n>This was hard and it took 3 tries to pass, although I got quite used to them and found this easier with my practice. <n><n><n># Task 3<n>Below is an instruction that describes the task to do.<n><n>###  Examples of how to do the task<n><n>### Instrection:<n><n>* Write a description of how you would:<n><n>* Calculate 4,240,000 minus 54,000 to get your answer in cents.<n>* 4,245,000<n>* This answer was a little easier than the last one because I simply added the digits to form a number.<n>* However when you do so you will always get a positive answer.<n><n>* Write the equation (a+b+c)/2 which equals ______.<n><n>* (√944)/2=62.2<n>* There are two ways to get the square root in the question one was adding both positive and negative numbers to form a bigger number and getting the square root of it. The other one is adding two of the same numbers together. You could get the negative answer (780).<n><n>* The equation 4x=295 is already written in scientific notation with the number 295 and then the variable x.<n>* Use the formula to convert the equation to standard form<n><n>* 4100<n>* <n>  <n># Task 1<n>Below is an example of some input to look at.<n><n>### Task A :Write a task.<n><n><n>How did you do your task?<n>This was difficult in the end because of the calculations and the reading of the words. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:The window of the Honda was hit from the inside, not the outside. Where was most of the the broken glass found? Choices:  A: bridge B: in spain C: beach D: field E: street<n><n>### Response:		<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:If a person wants to buy a radio, where are they likely to go? Choices:  A: race track B: kentucky derby C: american southwest D: triple crown E: horse derby<n><n>### Response:		Race track<n><n>### Demratiation:<n><n>### Rationales: 1.) Question: Everybody seemed to have a(n) horse not just the regular gamble, which event always bring out the biggest crowd to the sport?, what it tells us is that there wasn't just one person or event gambling or betting on the event, everyone gambled and they all had horses. Analysing the options given:<n><n>  -  Race track (Option A) is the only option that makes sense.<n>  -  Kentucky Derby (Option B) is only gambling when the actual race is not even there; thus, this option is invalid.<n>  -  American Southwest (Option D) is invalid because it is talking about the horse and event which is not American, however, horse is.<n>  -  Triple Crown (Option E) is invalid since it states everyone did not have a horse<n><n>2.) Rationales: A: Race track<n><n>Answer:  Race track<n><n>## C# Instruction: You will read the following instructions for the next task. If you receive a letter that contains the following note, then you must find out your spouse’s favorite color.<n><n>**Task (in a blank space): Write a response that appropriatley complies with the request**<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Input:You will read the following instructions in the next task, if the request asks you to find your spouse’s favotire color.<n>Choices: A: black B: brown D: pink E: violet<n><n>Rationales:<n>1. We cannot find out someone's favorite color unless they had told us.<n>4. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:How can a person end up stopping standing in  puddle? Choices:  A: move away from B: laying in C: sweating D: movement E: walking out of<n><n>### Response:		<n>How could a person not end up stopping standing in the puddle?<n><n>### Discussion:<n>1. For the question to be answered, the answer needs to indicate the behavior for the person to not end up standing in a puddle. This is in part because the question doesn't make sense without context. 2. There's no reason why you can't walk through a puddle without stopping, though it may be an inconvenience to get wet and have to remove your shoes if possible.<n>3. There are reasons why a person ends up stopping standing in the<n>      puddle in terms of behavior. For example, the question may refer to a wet area where standing in the pudding becomes uncomfortable. It may refer to an icy puddle with a thin layer of ice, where there is an unintended danger of slipping from the pressure of standing in it. The key is that the answer is a behavior, as "not end up standing in a wet puddle" is an unlikely event that requires intervention. <n><n><n>

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:What do you fill with ink to print? Choices:  A: squid B: pencil C: newspaper D: fountain pen E: printer<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Solution:<n>D. fountain pen<n><n>Input:What do you fill ink with to print. Choices:  A  squid B  pencil C  newspaper D  fountain pen.<n><n>The choices provided can be rearranged as the pencil fills up with ink to print, this choice is eliminated. <n><n>Flipping the choice, a squid can be rearranged to ink up to fill to print.<n>D eliminated. <n>Filling the newspaper with ink would be to print a newspaper.<n>This would be to print a fountain pen.

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: Where could you find some plumbing that would not be of use to you if you are thirsty? Choices:  A: oil refineries B: wall C: show D: own home E: water fountain<n>Rationales: 1. The question asks where you would find some plumbing that would not be useful in relieving your thirst.<n>2. This means we're looking for a place where plumbing exists, but it doesn't carry potable water.<n>3. Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Hence, the answer is the oil refineries (Option A) as there wouldn't be drinkable water there.<n>Answer: A: oil refineries<n><n>### Input:Where does a marmoset not usually go? Choices:  A: dictionary B: wilderness C: fly D: underground E: colorado<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Demand:The question here is asking where a<n>### marmoset doesn't often go and doesn't care much about colorado.<n>### Considering options:<n>Option A (dictionary): Not often visited (A) as in the dictionary, and marmosets don't seem to care much about colorado (B).<n>Option B (wilderness): Wilderness would be the right choice as marmosets don'<n>Option C (fly): A fly (C) would not go to a dictionary (Option A), the wilderness (Option B), or colorado (Option E). <n>Option D (underground):Underground (D) would be the right answer as marmosets wouldn't be found there and aren't usually seen in colorado (E).<n>Option E (colorado): Colorado (E) wouldn't be the right choice as it's not often visited (A) like dictionaries, and <n>### Answer: B: wilderness<n><n>### Instrucion:<n>Write a response that appropriately answers the question given below. Choose the one that best completes the request; then, for each response, select the one that is best supported by the narrative.<n><n>### Problem:<n>Write an essay in which you explain how Peter Skene Ogden's route across Utah differs from that followed by Brigham Young, Levi Stewart, and a group of Mormon pioneers.<n><n>### Solution:<n>When Peter Skene Ogden crossed the desert, he took a longer and more arduous route across the area. He made his way through Utah to the Pacific Ocean and returned home via the Oregon Trail. This trail was used more frequently than that followed by Young (B), Stewart, or the Mormons (A). <n><n>When Young arrived in Utah, he wanted to establish Utah as a center of Mormonism. Instead of following the route used by Ogden, he traveled on a route that was easier with more resources along the way. <n><n>Stewart decided not to travel alone, but rather, he and his group of Mormons decided to use the same route as Young. They had less resources along their journey and used them more sparingly. <n><n>### Choice options<n>- Young, Brigham B<n>- Stewart

"The Federal capital and its territories are the states of the United States." - US Constitution, Article IV, Section 3, paragraph 2<n><n>- Each state is the largest speech of the country.<n><n>- The answer to the question is A (each state).<n><n>### Solutions:<n>1. Choices:   A. I have a wonderful memory. B. I have wonderful memories. C. I am having a wonderful moment. D. I am having wonderful a moment. E. I'm having a wonderful moment.<n><n>### Answer:The first sentence is the correct option, stating I have a wonderful memory, as this uses a singular noun and a singular verb. The following sentences are all incorrect as they use the same verb for each subject. An Example of a sentence with a singular and a plural subject would be We are having a wonderful moment. The other sentences all use singular and plural subjects, making them incorrect.

Analyzing the options:<n>   - Oil refineries (Option A) use extensive plumbing, but it's for transporting oil, not water.<n>   - The Wall (Option B) might have plumbing inside it for water transportation, which you could possibly use if you were thirsty.<n>   - The Show (Option C) could refer to a variety of things, including shows with plumbing displays. But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4. Answer: Choice 'D' i.e. your own home.<n>```<n>

But these would probably have potable water.<n>   - Own home (Option D) would assuredly have useful plumbing for drinking water.<n>   - Water fountain (Option E) definitely would have plumbing carrying potable water.<n>4.
